Mary Wolcott of Windsor CT

2nd daughter of Henry and Elizabeth Wolcott of Windsor CT.

Revised February 2026
These web pages are intended for genealogical research purposes only and may not be used elsewhere without permission, but linking is allowed without need of approval. Questions and additions or corrections may be sent to Eric Wolcott, (ewolcott6 at gmail.com).

Navigate this page by clicking on the links to move through ancestors, children, and some spouses; the arrows to open additional details; or use Edit/Find to search for specific names within this page. Included here are the first seven generations from the target individual.
(1) Mary Wolcott1 b. ABT 1622 Tolland, Somerset, England, d. 16 SEP 1689 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesMARY came to America with her sister and younger brother about 1635. She and her husband died the same day.
m. 25 JUN 1646 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Job Drake, b. 1619 Wiscombe, Devonshire, England, d. 16 SEP 1689 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesJOB came to America in 1630 with his family on the "Winslow Fleet". He and his wife died on the same day of a disease that caused many deaths at Windsor in 1689 including two of his brothers, one sister in law, and one brother-in-law. His will said "I leave unto my wife the use of my dwelling house & barn. orchard & homelot except that which I give unto my son, Job, with my pasture I bought of Goodman Bissell, the land in the Little Meadow & the 10 acres of land I had of my brother, Christopher, & the inclosed lands...unto my son Job 6 acres of land that I had of my father Drake...my dwelling house, barn orchard and homelot with all my land within the township of Windsor...provided that he record to his son Job that house and that part of the homelott which he now enjoyeth...at 21 years of age...to my daughter Elizabeth the 4 acres of land in the Great Meadow that I bought of Goodman Thrall at my wife's decease. I give to Ephraim Colton 40 shillings and small rapier. I have given to my grchild Israel Dewey 2 young steers as also a chest marked E. D. To my grchild Susanna Packer my land at Greenfield.... I give to Joseph Dewey L4.... I give to my Grandchild Mary Drake that which is due me from my Father Drake's estate also from my brother Joseph's estate, also L4. I give to my grson Joseph Dewey land over the river...which was my father Drake's I give to my grchild Job Colton L5...and a gun. I give to Elizabeth my son Job's wife 50 shillings...the remainder of my estate to be divided amongst my children, that is to Job, Abigail, Elizabeth, and Esther...my son Job Drake to be sole Executor...." SOURCE CITATION: Title: Colonial Families of the United States Source Comments: NS16043
Subtree size: 2296 nodes.
7 children: Abigail, Mary, Job, Elizabeth, Joseph, Hepzibah, Hester "Esther".
(2) Abigail Drake2 (Mary Wolcott1) b. 28 SEP 1648 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 17 NOV 1696 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.

(7) Jefferson Cooley7 (Philetus Cooley6, Lois Holcomb5, Hannah Loomis4, Hannah Dewey3, Abigail Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 15 SEP 1800 Granby, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 20 DEC 1840 Granby, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesJEFFERSON graduated from Yale University and taught school at Granby. He studied law under Jared Griswold of Hartford. In 1836 he became Preceptor of the Poughkeepsie Academy. He was made Principal of the Academy at Sharon, Connecticut, in 1837.

(3) David Dewey3 (Abigail Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 11 JAN 1676 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 30 NOV 1712 Westfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
NotesDAVID was a weaver. He was a member of the Westfield church for 12 years, and was made a deacon in 1712. Several of his spiritual writing were published in a commemerative pamphlet after his death.
m. ABT 1699 Westfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Sarah Loomis, b. 1682 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 AUG 1756 Westfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.

(6) Deborah Dewey6 (Joseph Dewey5, Charles Dewey4, David Dewey3, Abigail Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 11 AUG 1756 Hebron, Tolland Co., Connecticut, d. APR 1837 Ashtabula, Ashtabula Co., Ohio.
NotesDEBORAH and her husband moved from Lebanon, Connecticut, to Columbia Co., New York, and then Delhi, Delaware Co., New York, in 1776, where eight of their nine children were born and raised. Her husband died from being thrown by a horse, when a spring-lance he carried in his pocket pierced his side. In 1802, Deborah took her four youngest children by ox drawn wagon to Ohio where her son, Abraham, and his wife had settled in 1801. They settled in a log cabin at what is now Austinburg, Ohio, with Indian neighbors. Her biography was printed in the 1915 Wolcott Society annual report.
m. DEC 1774 Hebron, Tolland Co., Connecticut, George Webster, b. Of Lebanon, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 1800 , Delaware Co., New York.
Subtree size: 11 nodes.
9 children: Cynthia, Abraham, Persis, Wealthy, Belinda, George, Polly, Philo, Lewis.

(5) Esther Hoar5 (Deborah Colton4, Ephraim Colton3, Mary Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 20 APR 1742 Brimfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 13 MAY 1818 Monson, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
m. 23 JUL 1768 Monson, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Simeon Keep, b. 27 FEB 1737 Brimfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 22 JUL 1829 Monson, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesSIMEON was a Lieutenant in Capt. James Sherman's Co., Col. Ebenezer Larned's Regt., Massachusetts militia, and in Capt. Reuben Munn's Co., 1st Regt., Hampshire County militia. He was in Capt. Aaron Charles' Co., Lt. Col. Timothy Robinson's Regt., Hampshire Co., militia at Ticonderoga, 24 February 1777. He lived in the part of Brimfield which later became Monson.
Subtree size: 39 nodes.
9 children: Seth, Simeon, Roxana, Abigail, Esther, Lettice, Joseph, Ethan, Warham.
(6) Seth Keep6 (Esther Hoar5, Deborah Colton4, Ephraim Colton3, Mary Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 10 MAY 1771 Monson, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 8 JUN 1857 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
NotesSeth removed to Vermont, after marriage, and in 1801 moved to Homer, New York. He was a farmer, as were all his sons. He was for many years a member of the Congregational church.
m. 23 JAN 1798 Lovisa Hitchcock, b. 24 MAY 1772 Brimfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 10 NOV 1855 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.

(7) Lamira Goodell Keep7 (Simeon Keep6, Esther Hoar5, Deborah Colton4, Ephraim Colton3, Mary Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 5 JAN 1805 Monson, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 15 NOV 1873 .
NotesLAMIRA and her husband purchased a home in 1854. It became a dairy farm, and had several small rock quarries. In 1856, Marcus conveyed the home to his nephew, Edward Keep, as his own children had all predeceased him. Marcus' estate was divided between his nephew and neice, Edward and Mary Keep, who he had raised. The home is now the Keep Homestead Museum.
m. 20 JAN 1830 Marcus Chapin, b. , d. .

m. 1822 William King, b. 9 NOV 1796 Pawlet, Rutland Co., Vermont, d. 3 SEP 1868 West Winfield, Herkimer Co., New York.
Spouse NotesWilliam was a Captain in the Calvary. He was a teamster, hauling freight between Albany and Buffalo, New York until the Erie Canal put him out of business.

(3) Sarah Drake3 (Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 10 MAY 1686 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 20 JAN 1747 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 3 DEC 1702 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Roger Wolcott, b. 4 JAN 1679 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 17 MAY 1767 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesROGER said that he never attended school in his life, but was taught at home by his mother. At the age of 12 he was apprenticed to a weaver. On reaching adulthood he educated himself by reading, and was admitted to the Bar. He built a home at East Windsor in 1704. Roger was chosen a Selectman of Windsor in 1707, a Representative to the Connecticut General Assembly in 1709, and a member of the Bench of Justices in 1710. He was in charge of the Connecticut commissary supplies in an expedition to Canada in 1711, during Queen Anne's War. In 1714 he was appointed to the Governor's Council. In 1724 he was appointed Judge of the County Court and in 1732 Judge of the Superior Court. He built a ferry across the Connecticut River in 1735, which he sold to the town of Windsor in 1736. In 1741 he became Deputy Governor and Chief Justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court. He was presiding judge in a trial at Winham, where Betty Shaw was convicted of infanticide and hung. Roger was appointed Major General, in command of the Connecticut troops that were part of the expeditions to Cape Breton and the siege of Louisburg in 1745. He was second in command under Sir William Pepperill. In 1750 he was elected Governor of Connecticut, serving until 1754. Roger fell from public favor due to a Spanish merchant's claim for damages when his ship was detained, for which the Assembly blamed the Governor, and so he was defeated for re-election. Roger was granted the right to operate a ferry boat on the Connecticut River near South Windsor. It is said that he became wealthy through land speculation. In 1720, he and seven others purchased 10,000 acres of land in Vermont from the Colony of Connecticut. They sold this land to settlers. While he was Governor, he was accused of encouraging the Susquehanna Company, a group of Connecticut investors who sold to settlers land in Northern Pennsylvania that Connecticut and Pennsylvania both claimed. Roger's son, Oliver, was a member of this company. It was later determined that neither Connecticut or the Susquehanna Company had a legal right to this land. Roger retired from public life, retiring to farming and literary pursuits. He published at least three of his writings, one being "Poetical Meditations, Being the Improvement of Some Vacant Hours", printed in 1725, said to have been the first book of poetry printed in the colonies. The second was an ecclesiastical tract about the history and liberties of the Congregational church, printed in 1761. The third was "A Letter to the Freemen of Connecticut", which appeared in the "Connecticut Gazette" in 1761. A pair of silver cups he presented to the Congregational Church at East Windsor have "R W 1756 engraved on them. His estate was valued at 1,805L. Among the bequests in his will were a silver tankard and cup left to his sons Erastus and Oliver Wolcott. Erastus bequeathed the tankard to his son, Erastus. They have the arms of the Shropshire family of Walcott engraved on them. Samuel Wolcott, the author of "The Wolcott Memorial", had the tankard in his possession in 1879. Roger's will also left land at Tolland, Connecticut, and a seal, ring, and a gun to his son, Alexander; land at Podunk, a silver sword, gold buttons, and a gun to his son, Josiah; his home at Windsor and a ferry boat to his son, Erastus; land at Litchfield, Hartford, Colebrook, and Wimdsor and a cannister to his son, Oliver; land at Windsor to be divided between his sons, Alexander, Erastus and Oliver; a watch to his son, Alexander; land at Windsor and Podunk to his grandsons, Roger and Epaphras; 130L to his grandson, Parmenio; land at Windsor, Bolton, and Wellington to his daughter, Maryanne; 15L to his daughter, Ursula; and the balance to be divided among his children. Gravestone reads: "Here lyeth the body of the Hon. Roger Wolcott, Esq., of Windsor, who for serveal years was Governor of the Colony of Connecticut died May 17th, Anno tatis 89, Salutis 1767. Births highest station end in here he lies And dust to dust coneludes her noblest song."
Subtree size: 979 nodes.
15 children: Roger, Elizabeth, Alexander, Samuel, Alexander, Sarah, Sarah, Hepzibah, Josiah, Erastus, Epaphras, Erastus, Ursula, Oliver, Mariann.
(4) Roger Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 14 SEP 1704 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 10 OCT 1759 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER lived in South Windsor, his property adjoining that of his uncle, Henry. He was a Representative for Windsor at the General Assembly, a Major in the Connecticut militia, a member of the Council, and Judge of the Hartford County Court and the Superior Court of Connecticut. Roger was one of those appointed to revise the laws of the Connecticut Colony, and was one of three commissioners appointed by the Colony of Connecticut to meet at Albany in 1745 with representatives of other colonies, to discuss a plan for union. He was one of the subscribers to the Susquehanna Land Company in 1753.
m. 10 OCT 1728 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Mary "Mara" Newberry, b. 3 FEB 1710 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 5 JUN 1758 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 179 nodes.
11 children: Roger, Marah, Roger, Sarah, Roger, Epaphras, Mary, Emeline, Parmenio, Amelia, Martha.

m. 26 APR 1758 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Elisha Steele, b. 7 OCT 1728 Tolland Township, Tolland Co., Connecticut, d. 17 AUG 1773 Tolland Township, Tolland Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesELISHA graduated from Yale College in 1750, and was the first lawyer in Tolland, Connecticut. He was a justice of the peace and elected to the state legislature six times. His marriage was also recorded at Tolland.

m. ABT 1782 Roger Wolcott, b. 25 MAY 1760 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 19 DEC 1799 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesROGER was at East Windsor in 1790 with 2 males over 16, 1 male under 16, 2 females, and 1 free Negro. His widow and her three daughters moved from Bridgewater, Connecticut, to Evans Mills, New York, after his death. The widow and her unmarried daughter, Polly, lived with her daughter, Sarah Wolcott Rogers, at LeRoy, New York.

(5) Roger Wolcott5 (Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 10 NOV 1737 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 8 JAN 1798 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER marched to Boston at the Lexington alarm as an Ensign and standard bearer in Capt. Amasa Loomis' Co.. He was a member of the Executive Committee of the Susquahanna Company, a land developmeny company formed to market land in the Wyoming Valley of Pennsylvania. In 1790 his family consisted of 2 males over 16, 1 male under 16, 3 females, and 1 free Negro at East Windsor, Connecticut.

NotesCORNELIUS drowned in Podunk Brook, while crossing on a plank when the river was flooding. His funeral was recorded in the diary of Rev. Thomas Robbins. Podunk Brook is between Windsor and Hartford, Connecticut.

(7) Oliver Wolcott7 (Cornelius Wolcott6, Roger Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 26 JUL 1796 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 26 NOV 1872 .
NotesOLIVER Wolcott, 50, born Connecticut, was living at Barre, New York, in 1830. He was there in 1840 with 1 male 40-50, 1 female 40-50, and 3 young females under 15. He was a farmer at Barre in 1850, with wife Mary 47, Laura Wolcott 17, Martha Wolcott 14, and William Borrows 10. In 1850 William Borrows was no longer with him. In 1860 he was at Barre with Mary and Laura S. Woolcott. In 1865 he was living with his daughter, Laura, at Barre. In 1875, part of Barre became the town of Albion.
m. 27 APR 1826 Enfield, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Mary Mumford, b. 7 SEP 1799 ,, Connecticut, d. 31 MAY 1864 .
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
4 children.
(7) Abner Wolcott7 (Cornelius Wolcott6, Roger Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 24 AUG 1798 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 8 OCT 1854 Rock Island, Rock Island Co., Illinois.
NotesABNER was a millwright. He moved to Iowa in 1837. He was one of the first three County Commissionesr for Johnson County, Iowa, elected in 1838. He served on the first Grand Jury and made out the first tax list for the county. In 1841 Abner Woolcott of Johnson Co., Iowa, purchased 80 acres of government land in Iowa. He left Iowa in 1843 for Rock Island, Illinois. He purchased a farm on Lowell Island near Milan, Illinois. In 1850 he was a millwright at Rock Island Co., Illinois, with wife Elizabeth, 25 or 29 born Ohio, and Cornelius 4, and John 5 mo. both born Illinois.
m. 8 APR 1844 , Rock Island Co., Illinois, Elizabeth Ann Wisecarver, b. 1825 ,, Ohio, d. .

4 children.

NotesROGER is said to have "Gone South".

(7) Cornelius Wolcott7 (Cornelius Wolcott6, Roger Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 2 SEP 1807 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 JAN 1848 Springfield, Hampshire, after 1812 Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
NotesCORNELIUS Woolcott of Enfield married Sophia Hall of Longmeadow at Longmeadow. His gravestone reads: Cornelius Wolcott died Jan. 13 1848 ae. 41.
m. 25 JAN 1827 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Sophia Sweatland Hall, b. 13 JAN 1813 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 18 NOV 1858 Springfield, Hampshire, after 1812 Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesSOPHIA's last name is sometimes given as Hale, but her great-granddaughter, Lois Wolcott said it was Sophia Sweatland Hall. In 1880, Minerva Swetland, widow, born 1802 Connecticut, was living with Oliver Wolcott and listed as his aunt. Her gravestone reads: Sophia wife of Cornelius Wolcott died Nov. 18 1858 aged 71 yrs.

(5) Epaphras Wolcott5 (Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 21 MAY 1740 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 JAN 1825 .
NotesEPAPHRAS was at East Windsor, Connecticut, in 1790, with family of 1 male over 16 and 5 females. He is said to have enlisted in Capt. Giles Wolcott's Company and died while on that unit's expedition to Canada. If, so, the death date we have for him must be wrong. He is also said to have married at Rochester NY, which also seems to be in error.
m. JUN 1762 Mabel Burnham, b. 1735 East Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 27 MAR 1814 .

(7) Infant Pomeroy7 (Sarah Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 MAR 1796 Hadley, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts, d. 11 MAR 1796 Hadley, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts.

0 children.
(6) James Wolcott6 (Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 19 APR 1766 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 29 APR 1849 Wheatland, Monroe Co., New York.
NotesJAMES lived at East Windsor, Connecticut, where the birth of his sons, Anson, James, and Epaphras was recorded. He was there in 1790 with a family of 1 male over 16, 2 males under 16, and 1 female. He was an officer in the militia during in the War of 1812. His sword was given to his grandson, James MacGregor Wolcott, and was passed on to James' grandaughter, Jessie Humphrey Hunt. He settled at East Bloomfield, Ontario Co., New York, where he lived for many years. He was living at Bloomfield in 1830. He and his wife later moved to Wheatland, New York, to live with their daughter, Miriam. A monument in the Wheatland Baptist Cemetery lists his children, Anson, Epaphras, James, Norman, and Miriam, and says: Anson married Lurinda Hawley Gillett at Mendon, NY. A successful and beloved teacher of Indians, English and deaf and dumb children. They settled in East Bloomfield NY. Prospered, were honored members of Bristol Baptist Church and large contributors. They had eight children." A small book about his descendants was printed by Chandler Wolcott in 1907.
m. JAN 1786 Wheatland, Monroe Co., New York, Miriam Munsell, b. 15 JAN 1767 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 24 JAN 1850 Wheatland, Monroe Co., New York.
Subtree size: 8 nodes.
7 children: Anson, Epaphras, James, Norman, Miriam, Sarah, Sarah.
(7) Anson Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 APR 1787 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 17 OCT 1864 East Bloomfield, Ontario Co., New York.
NotesANSON came from the Springfield Armory, where he was employed, to Bloomfield, New York, to join his brother, Epaphras, in operating a distillery. Epaphras moved to Rochester, and Anson was joined by his brother, Norman. In 1826, Anson and Norman of Bloomfield registered a patent for "distilling all kinds of liquor". In 1827 they registered another patent for "extracting alcohol from common spirits by steam. Anson also patented an improved still for making alcohol from apples in 1836. In 1837 he deeded land at Ontario County, New York, to his brother, James Wolcott, Jr. He and his brother, Epaphras, also started a silk business, raising their own silkworms. He was at East Bloomfield in 1860 with Lurinda, Lurinda, Esther, and Emily Wolcott. In 1860 Anson Wolcott of East Bloomfield had a storekeeper's license. A monument to the children of James and Miriam Wolcott at Wheatland Baptiat Cemetery reads: "Anson married Lurinda Hawley Gilette at Mendon, NY. A successful and beloved teacher of Indians, English and deaf and dumb children. They settled in East Bloomfield NY. Prospered, were honored members of Bristol Baptist Church and large contributors. They had eight children."
m. 29 MAR 1821 Mendon, Monroe Co., New York, Lurinda Hawley Gillett, b. 1802 , d. 17 AUG 1869 Canandaigua, Ontario Co., New York.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
7 children.
(7) Epaphras Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 APR 1789 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 AUG 1852 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York.
NotesEPAPHRAS was employed at the Springfield Armory. He left there and walked to New York state about 1808, and in 1811 purchased land in Wayne County, in what is now the town of Wolcott. He moved to Bloomfield, Ontario County, where he deeded land to Thomas and Benjamin Wheeler in 1814, Nathaniel, Lyman, and William Keyes in 1821, Richard Paul in 1821, nson Wolcott in 1821, Timothy Wilder in 1825, and Norman Wolcott in 1826. He appears on the Bloomfield 1820 census. His brother, Anson, joined him there in the operation of a distillery. In 1827 he moved to Rochester, where in 1830 he built the Wolcott Distillery and the Wolcott Tavern which he managed. His large frame house is still standing on the southwest corner of Mt. Hope Avenue and Clarissa St., looking much as it did in 1830 when the forest came to the very door of the house.

He is on the 1830 census at Brighton, Monroe Co., New York, which is near Rochester. Epaphras was a member of the First Baptist Church and was often called upon to speak at public meetings.
m. 25 MAY 1811 Naomi Paul, b. 19 AUG 1791 , d. 11 NOV 1853 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
7 children.
(7) James Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 5 MAY 1791 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 4 APR 1866 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesJAMES settled at Rome, Oneida Co., New York, where all his children were born. He had a sawmill at Rome. He was at Chicago, Illinois, in 1860, and died there in the home of his son, Ebenezer. James was a Presbyterian.
m. 13 NOV 1814 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, Lovisa Emily Gould, b. 15 JUL 1792 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. ABT 1854 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
9 children.
(7) Norman Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 4 APR 1794 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 OCT 1852 Wolcott's Landing, Ohio Co., Kentucky.
NotesNORMAN came to Bloomfield, New York, to help his brother, Anson, operate a silkworm business. He moved to Warren County, Ohio, about 1819. Norman, his wife and infant son, and the Henry family, left there on a flatboat, en route to New Orleans. Coming down the Ohio River they encountered a lot of ice, so they spent the winter of 1820 camped at the mouth of the Green River. The Henry family continued down the river, but left their son, James, with the Wolcotts. James later married Norman's daughter. In the spring, Norman, continued up the Green River and settled at a place on the Green River, 6 miles north of South Carrollton, Kentucky. This became known as Wolcott's Landing. There he built a grist mill. He operated the mill until he got his arm crushed in the mill machinery. He later died of the injury.

1850 Ohio, Ohio Co. KY:Norman Walcott 56 Massachusetts, miller
Mary A Walcott F 54 North Carolina
Oliver H Walcott M 22 New York, Distiller
Nancy J Walcott F 19 New York
Isabella Cole F 65 North Carolina
next to James Walcott,29, b. OH, distiller
Louisa Walcott, 15
m. 1 FEB 1820 , Warren Co., Ohio, Mary Ann Mac Gregor, b. 1797 Aberdeen,, Scotland, d. 24 OCT 1862 Wolcott's Landing, Ohio Co., Kentucky.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
5 children.
(7) Miriam Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 28 NOV 1795 ,, Connecticut, d. 28 JUL 1878 .
m. 22 MAR 1820 Rawson Harmon, b. 3 SEP 1794 Mumford, Monroe Co., New York, d. 24 JUN 1873 Mumford, Monroe Co., New York.
Spouse NotesRAWSON's was a noted wheat farmer and his farm was called Wheatland Farm. He was awarded a gold meadal at the first World Fair held in the Crystal Palace near London, England for his display of 35 varieties of wheat all grown on his Wheatland Farm. He served in the War 1812. In 1846 he opened an agricultural school on his farm, of which he was principal.

(6) Mary Wolcott6 (Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 26 JUL 1773 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
m. 26 NOV 1795 Wilbraham, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Aaron Davis, b. , d. .
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(5) Mary Wolcott5 (Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 4 APR 1742 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
m. 22 APR 1764 Pomfret, Windham Co., Connecticut, Jesse Goodell, b. 8 DEC 1738 Pomfret, Windham Co., Connecticut, d. 14 JUN 1776 .
Spouse NotesJESSE studied divinity at Yale University and was licensed to preach in 1763. He organized at church at Westminister, Vermont, and was installed as pastor in 1767. "His carer at Westminister was cut short by the discovery of some immoralities in which he had been concerned, and he left town secretly, without a dismission from his office about the first of December, 1769. Mrs. Goodell's brothers are said to have taken her back to their home in Connecticut with her two children. ("Biographical Sketches of the Graduates of Yale College"). He was a chaplain in the Revolutionary Army, and may have died during the War.
Subtree size: 4 nodes.
3 children: Martha, Thomas, Sarah.

(5) Parmenio Wolcott5 (Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 17 APR 1746 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 9 JAN 1812 Rome, Oneida Co., New York.
NotesPARMENIO moved to Rome, New York, shortly after his marriage. He had a farm there. However, he appears on the 1790 census at East Windsor, with a family of 2 males over 16, 1 male under 16, and 3 females. Information about his family is found in an 1825 Bible, apparently recorded by his daughter, Mary Wolcott Stone.
m. 1767 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Mary Ballard, b. 11 OCT 1750 Lancaster, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, d. 2 MAR 1833 Rome, Oneida Co., New York.
Subtree size: 47 nodes.
8 children: Alfred, Parmenio, Prudence, , Josiah, Mary "Polly", Prudence, Lydia.
(6) Alfred Wolcott6 (Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 14 APR 1769 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 20 NOV 1835 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesALFRED came to the Western Reserve, which later became Ohio, in 1796. He had been hired as a surveyor by John Young, the founder of Youngstown. He also surveyed the towns of Canfield and Bristol, for which the Connecticut Land Co. gave him 350 acres of land as payment. He erected the first building in Bristol Township. His marriage to Mary Gilson in 1800 was the first marriage in the county, but the ceremony was actually performed in Pennsylvania as there was no minister in Mahoning County. Mary must have died soon after their marriage, for by 1806 he had bought half of Boston Township in Portage County, and had gone there to clear the ground for his farm, and to build a log house for his new bride, Margaret Craig Wolcott. Alfred was a taxpayer in Portage Co. in 1808. This part of Portage County later became Summit County. Alfred was elected Justice of the Peace in the first election, and also serving as a fence-viewer. His old record book containing all cases that came to him as Justice was in the possession of his great-grandson, Oliver Wolcott, of Copley, Ohio. The Wolcott's daughter Malinda was the first white child born in Boston Township. In 1816 a log schoolhouse was built in the Wolcott neighborhood, and Alfred Wolcott was the first schoolmaster. It is said that there was a tiny school near his home in which he taught as early as 1812. Alfred served in Capt. Rial McArthur's Co. from August to October 1812, during the War of 1812. His will left his land, about 119 acres, to his wife, Margaret, with the exception of a half acre left as a burial ground for the township of Boston, now called the Fairview Cemetery, established in 1890.
m. 1800 Mary Gilson, b. , d. .
Subtree size: 2 nodes.
1 child: Lydia.
(7) Lydia Wolcott7 (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1804 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1 JUN 1834 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesLYDIA died of Tuberculosis, age 32.
m. 23 FEB 1823 Boston, Summit Co., Ohio, George Leach, b. 1798 Goshen, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 31 JUL 1853 .
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
5 children.
(6) Alfred Wolcott6 (Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 14 APR 1769 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 20 NOV 1835 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesALFRED came to the Western Reserve, which later became Ohio, in 1796. He had been hired as a surveyor by John Young, the founder of Youngstown. He also surveyed the towns of Canfield and Bristol, for which the Connecticut Land Co. gave him 350 acres of land as payment. He erected the first building in Bristol Township. His marriage to Mary Gilson in 1800 was the first marriage in the county, but the ceremony was actually performed in Pennsylvania as there was no minister in Mahoning County. Mary must have died soon after their marriage, for by 1806 he had bought half of Boston Township in Portage County, and had gone there to clear the ground for his farm, and to build a log house for his new bride, Margaret Craig Wolcott. Alfred was a taxpayer in Portage Co. in 1808. This part of Portage County later became Summit County. Alfred was elected Justice of the Peace in the first election, and also serving as a fence-viewer. His old record book containing all cases that came to him as Justice was in the possession of his great-grandson, Oliver Wolcott, of Copley, Ohio. The Wolcott's daughter Malinda was the first white child born in Boston Township. In 1816 a log schoolhouse was built in the Wolcott neighborhood, and Alfred Wolcott was the first schoolmaster. It is said that there was a tiny school near his home in which he taught as early as 1812. Alfred served in Capt. Rial McArthur's Co. from August to October 1812, during the War of 1812. His will left his land, about 119 acres, to his wife, Margaret, with the exception of a half acre left as a burial ground for the township of Boston, now called the Fairview Cemetery, established in 1890.
m. 27 MAY 1806 Youngstown, Trumbull Co., Ohio, Margaret Craig, b. 1785 Wheeling, Ohio Co., West Virginia, d. 28 FEB 1863 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
Subtree size: 9 nodes.
8 children: Malinda, Edytha, Parmenio, Alfred, Josiah, Darius, Mary, Simon Perkins.
(7) Malinda Wolcott7 (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 14 APR 1807 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1878 .
m. 9 OCT 1828 Hudson, Columbia Co., New York, John Sherman Oviatt, b. 18 JUL 1805 Goshen, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 1861 .
Spouse NotesJOHN was the grandson of Samuel Oviatt who hired Alfred Wolcott to survey 4,000 acres in the Western Reserve.
Subtree size: 1 node.

(7) Edytha Wolcott7 (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 3 OCT 1808 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 12 APR 1878 Bluffton, Allen Co., Ohio.
m. 10 JAN 1828 , Portage Co., Ohio, Zebulon Stow, b. 8 APR 1802 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 28 SEP 1871 Cascade, Kent Co., Michigan.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
5 children.
(7) Parmenio Wolcott7 (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 11 MAY 1810 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 17 JUL 1871 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesPARMENIO was a farmer. He was a town trustee of Norfolk, Ohio, from 1862 to 1871. In 1870 Parmenio was at Northfield, Summit Co., Ohio, with Emeline and James M. Wolcott. He purchased a house and land in Summit Co., Ohio, from George Thompson in 1853. It was a stone farmhouse in the Greek Revival style and is now on the Ohio Historic Registry. Three generations of Wolcotts lived here, and operated a cheese factory on the property. It was owned by his son, James, who deeded it to Avis G. Wolcott in 1898. Avis sold it to Henry E. Bourne in 1913.
m. 10 JUN 1835 , Portage Co., Ohio, Emeline Tupper, b. 27 MAY 1815 Parishville, St. Lawrence Co., New York, d. 27 JUN 1894 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesEMELINE lived with her son, James, in 1880.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
6 children.
(7) Alfred Wolcott7 (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 28 JAN 1812 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 17 MAR 1892 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesALFRED and his 15 year old wife set up housekeeping in a log cabin on his father's farm at Boston Township, Ohio. The log cabin was replaced by a large farm house, and was expanded into a four hundred acre farm. Alfred served several terms in the Ohio legislature, and he saw to it that those of his children who wished it had a college education and professional training. In 1880 he was at Boston, Ohio, with Mary Ann, John, Anna A., Alfred, and Fremont Wolcott. His farm is now the Boston Mills Golf Course.
m. 18 APR 1831 Mary Ann Scoville, b. 1816 ,, Connecticut, d. 23 JUN 1882 Boston, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesMARY came to Hudson, Ohio, with her mother.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.

(7) Darius Wolcott7 (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 12 DEC 1816 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 29 AUG 1894 Thompson, Geauga Co., Ohio.
NotesDARIUS and Sophia were at Thompson, Ohio, in 1870. He was appointed a Justice of the Peace at Thompson in 1873. He was a farmer at Thompson, Ohio, in 1880. Buried with him and his wife at Maple Grove Cemetery was Minnie Wolcott, possibly a daughter.

(6) Parmenio Wolcott6 (Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 17 DEC 1770 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. ,, New York.
NotesPARMENIO Wolcott, Jr., of Cayuga County, served as ensign in Capt. Ellis' Co., New York militia, in 1810-1812. He was later a farmer at Yorkshire, Cattaraugus Co., New York. In 1840 he moved to Michigan, buying land in Washtenaw and Barry Counties, and living in Washtenaw County. He later returned to New York and resided with his son, Alfred.
m. 9 AUG 1798 Westmoreland, Oneida Co., New York, Anna "Annie" Fulkerson, b. 1779 Freehold, Monmouth Co., New Jersey, d. 24 JUL 1874 Orangeville, Barry Co., Michigan.
Spouse NotesANNA was with her son, Alfred, at Orangeville, Michigan, in 1870. Anna Wolcott, widow, died 1874, Orangeville, Michigan, age 97 years, 8 mo., 10 days.
Subtree size: 10 nodes.
8 children: Lydia, Laura, Littoria, Alfred, Henry "Harry", Parmenio, Samuel B., Clarinda Matilda.

(7) Alfred Wolcott7 (Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 5 JUN 1806 , Tompkins Co., New York, d. LaGrange, Lorain Co., Ohio.
NotesALFRED moved from Tompkins County, New York, to Erie County in 1840, where he had a hotel and a farm. He then had a hotel at Cattaraugus county, New York, for 10 years. He was a farmer at Prairieville, Michigan, in 1850. He was a farmer at Orangeville, Michigan, in 1860, with Mary and Anna, his mother. He was at Prairieville, Michigan in 1870 with Mary H. and Anne. He moved to join his son, William, at La Grange and in 1880 was farming at LaGrange, Ohio.
m. 20 MAR 1834 Mary Henrietta Ledoyt, b. 1834 ,, Connecticut, d. .

(7) Henry "Harry" Wolcott7 (Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 19 APR 1809 ,, New York, d. ABT 1875 Vevay, Ingham Co., Michigan.
Notes HENRY was a farmer. He and his brother, Parmenio, moved to Washtenaw Co., Michigan, in the 1830s.
In the 1840s he and his brother, Samuel, settled in White Oak Twp. Ingham Co., Michigan. They were on the tax rolls there in 1844.

1850 Vevay MI:
Henry Woolcott 40, b. NY, farmer
Marinda Woolcott 37, b. NY
Sarah Woolcott 14, b. NY
Delas Woolcott 7, b. MI

1860 Vevay, Michigan
Henry Wolcott 61, b. NY, farmer
Malinda Wolcott 57, b. NY
Delos Wolcott 27, b. MI, farm labor

1870 Vevay, Michigan.
Henry Wolcott 61, b. NY
Malinda Wolcott 57, b. NY
Delos Wolcott 27, b. MI

1880 Vevay MI:
Delos Wolcott 37,b. MI, farmer
Allie Wolcott 29, b. NY
Harry Wolcott 6, son, b. MI
Melinda Wolcott 67, mother, b. NY
Selwin Brush 27, farm labor


1880 Vevay MI:
Delos Wolcott 37,b. MI, farmer
Allie Wolcott 29, b. NY
Harry Wolcott 6, son, b. MI
Melinda Wolcott 67, mother, b. NY
Selwin Brush 27, farm labor
m. 22 FEB 1835 Melinda Main, b. ABT 1813 North Stonington, New London Co., Connecticut, d. Vevay, Ingham Co., Michigan.
Spouse NotesMelinda was living with her son, Delos, at Vevay, Michigan, in 1880.

(7) Parmenio Wolcott7 (Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 22 JUL 1813 ,, New York, d. Orangeville, Barry Co., Michigan.
NotesPARMENIO was a farmer. In the 1830's he and his brother, Henry, moved to Washtenaw Co., Michigan. In 1837 Parmenio Wolcott Jr. of Washtenaw Co., Michigan, bought 80 acres of federal land in Washtenaw Co.. In the 1840's he settled in Barry Co., Michigan. He was a farmer at Orangeville, Michigan, in 1850 with Azina and Alfred Woolcott. He was living in Michigan in 1863. In 1860 he was a farmer at Orangeville, Barry Co., Michigan, with Alzina L. and Jerome.
m. 15 JAN 1841 , Jackson Co., Michigan, Alzina L. Turner, b. 1816 ,, New York, d. .

(7) Samuel B. Wolcott7 (Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 30 JUL 1815 ,, New York, d. 16 SEP 1870 Sharon, Washtenaw Co., Michigan.
NotesSAMUEL and his brother, Henry, were among the earliest settlers in White Oak Township, Ingham Co., Michigan. They were on a tax list there in 1844. He was a farmer at Sharon, Washtenaw Co. from 1850 to 1870. In 1860 he was with Marian, Frances, Marian, and Venning.
m. 24 FEB 1849 Sharon, Washtenaw Co., Michigan, Maria Ellen Matthews, b. 1829 ,, Michigan, d. ABT 1861 Sharon, Washtenaw Co., Michigan.

(6) Mary "Polly" Wolcott6 (Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 27 OCT 1778 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 27 JAN 1856 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
m. 17 DEC 1802 Nathan Stone, b. 14 OCT 1780 Brimfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 18 APR 1851 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
Spouse NotesNATHAN was a stone and brick mason, and a farmer. He settled at Homer, New York shortly after 1800. In 1820 he was elected a deacon of the Congregational Church. The Stone/Wolcott Bible, printed in 1825, was in the possession of Porter Bennett of Cortland, New York. He was at Homer, New York, in 1850, with Mary 71, Haydern 39, Vernon27, and Emily.
Subtree size: 10 nodes.
8 children: Hadassah, Melissa, Josiah Wolcott, Hadassah, Almira, Alphonso, Emily A., Vernon Thompson.

(7) Melissa Stone7 (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 6 DEC 1805 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 5 JUL 1883 .
m. APR 1835 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, David Corey, b. 14 MAY 1798 , d. 16 AUG 1874 .

3 children.
(7) Josiah Wolcott Stone7 (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 16 OCT 1807 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 10 MAY 1877 Glen Haven, Cayuga Co., New York.
NotesJOSIAH was a wagon maker, foundry worker and furnace maker. His obituary says his early years spent on his father's farm east of Homer. He learned wagon manufacturing from Mr. David Coye. Then he removed to Phelps, Ontario Co. where he resided 2 or 3 years. Immediately after his marriage in 1835, he returned to Homer and went into business with Mr. Coye and lived on Pine St. In 1838 removed to Moravia where he stayed until spring of 1853, when he returned to Homer and went into the foundry business with his brother Alphonso until 1872. He joined the Homer Congregational church in 1856. In 1873 he built a house on Main St. He was trustee of the First Religious Society of Homer.
m. FEB 1835 ,, New York, Elizabeth Ringer, b. 1816 , Ontario Co., New York, d. 21 JAN 1857 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
Spouse NotesElizabeth Ringer's surname has also been found as Rieger and Resger.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Josiah Wolcott Stone7 (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 16 OCT 1807 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 10 MAY 1877 Glen Haven, Cayuga Co., New York.
NotesJOSIAH was a wagon maker, foundry worker and furnace maker. His obituary says his early years spent on his father's farm east of Homer. He learned wagon manufacturing from Mr. David Coye. Then he removed to Phelps, Ontario Co. where he resided 2 or 3 years. Immediately after his marriage in 1835, he returned to Homer and went into business with Mr. Coye and lived on Pine St. In 1838 removed to Moravia where he stayed until spring of 1853, when he returned to Homer and went into the foundry business with his brother Alphonso until 1872. He joined the Homer Congregational church in 1856. In 1873 he built a house on Main St. He was trustee of the First Religious Society of Homer.
m. 2 FEB 1859 Marie Antoninette Whitney, b. 1824 , d. 28 AUG 1907 Syracuse, Onondaga Co., New York.

NotesHadassah was a school teacher in Dist. No. 10. She never married.

(7) Almira Stone7 (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 29 MAR 1815 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 3 NOV 1879 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
NotesALMIRA and her brothers, Josiah and Vernon, were charter member of the Congregational Church at Homer in 185.
m. 5 APR 1837 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, Lorenzo Bennett, b. 19 MAR 1812 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 9 JUL 1891 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
Spouse NotesLORENZO attended Cortland Academy at Homer and was a school teacher in New Jersey. In 1845 he established a business selling shoes.

(7) Alphonso Stone7 (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 15 APR 1818 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 23 MAR 1885 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
NotesAlphonso, for many years operated the Stone foundry on South Main Street, inconjunction with his sons, C.C. & L.A. Stone.

(7) Emily A. Stone7 (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1824 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 2 AUG 1903 .

(7) Vernon Thompson Stone7 (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 6 FEB 1824 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 12 DEC 1900 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
NotesVernon Thompson Stone was born on the farm east of Homervillage on Feb 6, 1824. He was educated at Cortland Academy and spent his entire live in Homer with the exception of two years spent in Hamilton, Canada and two years in Aurora, Illionis. He was married July 20, 1847 to Miss Emily Eliott. He was engaged in the mercantile business for some years with George J.J. Barber and C.O. Newton and also in the manufacture of wagons and other business enterprises. He was VP of Homer National Bank from its organization. He served as supervisor of Homer, superintendant of the poor from 1887-1890, village trustee, etc. He was a member of the board of education of Homer Academy. He was a member of the Congregational Church of Homer.
Vernon Stone's will contains the following information: "Vernon T. Stone of Homer gives to Glenwood Cemetery $150 in trust for care for his lot. To Mrs. Jennetta Cutway, niece of my wife Emily, of Tonawanda, Erie Co. NY $5 00. Remainder to wife Emily A. Stone for her life. After death of wife he gives to daughter Lottie M. Schermerhorn of Homer $5000 and remainder of his personal estate. If she is not living, the $5000 to go to adopted daughter. After deaths of wife and adopted daughter, gives to nephew Charles L. Stone of Homer $500 and residue of personal estate. To nephew Agustus H. Bennett and to nephew Eliot L. Stone of Homer and to niece May E. Van Hoesen, wife of Arthur Van Hoesen of Syracuse, NY. If Augustus Bennett not living, then to Lester P. Bennett and Frederick V. Bennett sons of Augustus. Wife Emily A. Stone and Augustus H. Bennett executors. After death of wife, adopted daugther, Dottie M. Schermerhorn in place of wife." 6 Jan 1899. Wit: S.S. Knox and Charles F. Brown residents of Cortland, NY. Codicil. Revokes bequest to Jennie Cutway. 3 Nov 1899. Wit: S.S. Knox and L.P. Hollenbeck of Cortland, NY.
m. 20 AUG 1847 Emily A. Elliott, b. 16 OCT 1823 ,, New York, d. 2 AUG 1903 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
Spouse NotesEmily Stone's will says: Emily A. Stone of Homer. "All to husband. After death of husband, to adopted daughter Lottie M. Schermerhorn. If Lottie dead, then to niece Mollie Brown of Suceltomt[?], Nevada Co. CA and Mary E. Von Hoesen, niece of husband of Syracuse, NY. Husband to be executor, or if he is death, Augustus H. Bennett, and Lottie M. Schermerhorn, executors."
Subtree size: 1 node.

m. 1811 Chauncey Keep, b. 5 NOV 1784 Monson, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 12 OCT 1853 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
Spouse NotesCHAUNCEY was one of the first Trustees of Cortland Academy in 1819 . He was a Whig and was elected a member of the New York State legislature in 1830 and again in 1836. Chauncey and his wife, Prudence, were 4th cousins.

(7) Henry Keep7 (Prudence Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 28 OCT 1820 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 4 MAY 1897 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesHENRY graduated from Union College in Schenectady, New York in 1839, and practiced law for several years. He was a partner with Philander Peck and Albert Keep in a dry goods business in Whitewater, Wiscosin. Im 1851 he opened a similar business in Chicago, called Peck, Keep & Co.
m. 5 MAY 1846 Phebe McClure, b. , d. 15 NOV 1896 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.

(7) Albert Keep7 (Prudence Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 30 APR 1826 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 1908 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesALBERT came from Fredonia to Whitewater with his brother, Henry, in 1847. He formed a parnership with Philander Keep to operate a retail business. In 1851 Peek & Keep entered the wholsale dry goods trade at Chicago. In 1856 Albert turned to real estate, and was hired to secure a right of way through Chicago for the Chicago & Nothwestern Railroad. He became a director of the railroad in 1865, and became President of the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad in 1883.
m. 6 APR 1853 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, Susan A. Williams, b. , d. 29 NOV 1859 .

(6) Roger Wolcott Lord6 (Amelia Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 13 JAN 1778 Lyme, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesROGER came from New London, Connecticut to Carlisle, New York, where he purchased a farm. He opened an inn and tavern in 1804. He married a grandaughter of Gov. Roger Sherman. "But the loss of property and love of ardent spirits brought him down to poverty in a few years, and he became dependant upon his four sisters, who followed him in a short time and established themselves as milliners, the first in town.... hen the shop was dull they taught school and gave lessons in fancy work, and were active in church work.

John L. Lord, age 55, was at Schoharie in 1855
m. Sherman, b. , d. .

m. 1803 , Montgomery Co., New York, John Boughten Roscoe, b. 3 JAN 1777 New Canaan, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, d. 9 NOV 1865 Carlisle, Schoharie Co., New York.
Spouse NotesJOHN B. Roscoe came from Essex Co., New York, to Carlisle, and settled with the Lord family in 1805, and was the first physician in Carlisle. Hen continued his practice for nearly 60 years. He purchased 10 acres of land in 1810 and settled there and had a family of 2 sons and 3 daughters.

(4) Roger Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 14 SEP 1704 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 10 OCT 1759 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER lived in South Windsor, his property adjoining that of his uncle, Henry. He was a Representative for Windsor at the General Assembly, a Major in the Connecticut militia, a member of the Council, and Judge of the Hartford County Court and the Superior Court of Connecticut. Roger was one of those appointed to revise the laws of the Connecticut Colony, and was one of three commissioners appointed by the Colony of Connecticut to meet at Albany in 1745 with representatives of other colonies, to discuss a plan for union. He was one of the subscribers to the Susquehanna Land Company in 1753.
m. 19 JUN 1759 Springfield, Hampshire, after 1812 Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Eunice Colton, b. 22 FEB 1706 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 29 MAR 1778 Bolton, Worcester Co., Massachusetts.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(4) Elizabeth Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 10 APR 1706 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 JUL 1775 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesELIZABETH received a pension from the British government for her husband's military service. It was paid in merchandise, which she sold from her home at Wintonbury, now Bloomfield. Her account books and scales used in this mercantile business for 1739 to 1741 were in the possession of her great-grandson. Oliver Dwight Filley of Bloomfield.
m. 27 AUG 1727 Roger Newberry, b. 4 JUN 1706 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 6 MAY 1741 ,, Cuba.
Spouse NotesROGER graduated from Yale College in 1726. He commanded a company of soldiers sent to fight in the West Indies, and died at sea while returning from this expedition. Roger and his wife, Elizabeth were second cousins.
Subtree size: 136 nodes.
7 children: Elizabeth, Hannah, Abigail, Roger, Sarah, Benjamin, Thomas.

(5) Roger Newberry5 (Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 30 JUN 1735 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 FEB 1814 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER lived on the Newberry homestead in Windsor until his death. He was a lawyer and a successful merchant. He held commissions as Lieutenant and as Captain under the English Crown, but at the commencement of the American Revolution he promptly engaged himself in the service of the Colonies. He was commissioned Major General in the Connecticut State militia. Roger served four years as a member of the Governor's Council. He was a Judge of Probate, and Judge of the County Court. He was a member of the upper house of the Connecticut Legislature from 1799 to 1809, and received an honorary degree from Yale College. Tradition says that he bore a striking resemblance to his maternal grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott. Roger and his wife, Eunice, were 2nd cousins.
m. 9 JAN 1759 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Hannah Allyn, b. ABT 1740 , d. 23 FEB 1760 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(5) Roger Newberry5 (Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 30 JUN 1735 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 FEB 1814 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER lived on the Newberry homestead in Windsor until his death. He was a lawyer and a successful merchant. He held commissions as Lieutenant and as Captain under the English Crown, but at the commencement of the American Revolution he promptly engaged himself in the service of the Colonies. He was commissioned Major General in the Connecticut State militia. Roger served four years as a member of the Governor's Council. He was a Judge of Probate, and Judge of the County Court. He was a member of the upper house of the Connecticut Legislature from 1799 to 1809, and received an honorary degree from Yale College. Tradition says that he bore a striking resemblance to his maternal grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott. Roger and his wife, Eunice, were 2nd cousins.

(7) John Strong Newberry7 (Henry Newberry6, Roger Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 22 DEC 1822 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesJOHN graduated from Western Reserve College in 1846 and received his M.D. from the Cleveland Medical College in 1848. He was in Europe in 1849/1850 and commenced the practice of medicine in 1851. In May 1855 he was appointed by the U.S. War Department as Surgeon and Geologist of Williamson's Expedition for the exploration of Northern California and Oregon, which took the next six years. He was then appointed to the Ives Expedition to Southern California and New Mexico. In 1861 he was appointed Secretary of the Western Department, U.S. Sanitary Commission. John was appointed Professor of Geology and Paleontology in the School of Mines, Columbia College, New York City. In 1860 he was appointed Chief of the Ohio State Geological Survey; was President of the New York Academy of Sciences, 1867-1889. He was President of the Torrey Botanical Club, 1886-1889; was an original incorporator of the National Academy of Sciences, and was President of the American Association for the Advacement of Science.
m. 12 OCT 1848 Sarah Brownell Gaylord, b. 16 DEC 1823 Madison, Madison Co., New York, d. .
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
7 children.

NotesALEXANDER was killed by a cart wheel.

(4) Samuel Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 JAN 1710 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 27 DEC 1717 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(4) Alexander Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 JAN 1712 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1795 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale in 1731 and "owned the Covenant" in 1733 at the First Church of New Haven. He studied medicine with Dr. Norman Morrison at Hartford, and accompanied his father as surgeon's mate in the expedition against Louisburg during the French and Indian Wars. He settled in Windsor, where he was a practicing physician from 1740 until the 1780s. He served as Justice of the Peace and Representative of the town to the General Assembly. He succeeded his brother, Roger, as a member of the Susquehanna Land Company, of which he was a member in 1774 and 1786. He was appointed Chairman of the Windsor Committee of Safety and was head of a commission to examine applicants for becoming surgeons in the Continental Army. For his services during the war, he was awarded land at Montgomery, Franklin Co., New Hampshire. Alexander wrote poetry, some of which was published. He owned a slave named Primus who assisted him in his medical work. Primus was freed by Alexander and was known as Dr. Primus Manumit, with his own medical practice. In the 1790 census, Alexander had 1 male over 16, 3 males under 16, 2 females, and 2 free Negros living in his home at Windsor. Alexander's home, built in 1745, stood at the top of the Broad St. Green in downtown Windsor. It was moved to make room for building that is now Arthurs Drug Store. It is now at 5 Moorlands St. in Windsor. It has a huge double fireplace, a birthing room, and a 5 ft. wide vat in the attic made from one huge tree.

In the case Alexander Walcott et al. v. James Swan et al., April 1800, an appeal from the Court of Chancery, where Swan and Alexander McRae sued Walcott, Smyth and Price, saying that on 21 July 1795 they entered into contract regarding lands in Russell County whereby McRae gave Smyth, the registrar of the land office, land warrants for 300,000 acres of land in Russel County. After this Walcott gave Smyth a considerable sum of money for which Smyth gave him the warrants for which Walcott took lands in Lee County of inferior value. These lands were included in a 650,000 acre survey made for Walcott and returned to Smyth who was to issue a patent to Walcott. The suit was to enjoin Smyth from issuing the patent to Walcott and to issue 300,000 acres to Swan, or that pary of the survey orininally entered on warrents of Swan. Alexander Walcott said that in June 1795 he, David Booth and Austin Nichols of Connecticut were in Montgomery Co., Virginia, and met with Smyth who proposed to survey for them a tract on the Big Sandy River. Walcott, Booth and Nichols were to return to Connecticut and secure the mone and meet Smyth on 20 Sep. following in Richmond and Smyth was to hold the said lands for them until then. They raise sufficient money to secure 1,500,000 acres of land and returned on 20 Sept to find Smyth gone, at which time Booth and Nichols relinquished to Walcott their rights to the contract. Smyth in the meantime had issued 300,000 to Swan, but later surveyed for Swan the better land in Lee County and for Walcott 650,00 acres in Russell County. Alexander Walcott was required to assign to James Swan 3000,000 of the 650,000 acres.
1797 land grant to Alexander Wolcott of 50,000 acres in Lee Co. Virginia by Gov. James Wood
In 1807 Diggs and Keith sued Alexander Wolcott in Middlesex C. Connecticut courts for promissory notes given by him for the purchase of land in Virginia.
1822 receipt to Alexander Wolcott for redemption of land returned delinquent by the sheriff of Lee Co. Virginia.
m. 4 DEC 1732 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Lydia Roswell Atwater, b. 18 OCT 1715 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 28 JAN 1776 Cromwell, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesLYDIA divorced her husband, Alexander Wolcott, at his request. Both remarried.

(5) Jeremiah Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 3 NOV 1733 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 12 MAY 1792 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesJEREMIAH was a physician at Branford, Connecticut. He may have been the Jeremiah Woolcott who served during the Revolutionary War. In 1773 Sarah Wolcott of Branford obtained a divorce from him

(6) Thomas Goodsell Wolcott6 (Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 17 AUG 1764 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 22 JAN 1847 New York City, New York.
NotesTHOMAS was expelled from Yale College in his Junior year for participating in a serious disorder and was not admitted to a degree until a year after his class had graduated. He received a BA from Yale College in 1783. He was a member of "Brothers in Unity", a Yale fraternity which maintained a library and reading room at Yale. . In 1790 he was at North Haven, Connecticut, with a family of 1 male over 16 and 3 females. He was teaching school at North Branford in 1792. In 1840 he was at New York City. He died in the Alms House at New York City.
m. 27 MAY 1789 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Lucy Hoffman, b. 5 FEB 1769 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1830 .
Subtree size: 7 nodes.

(7) Sarah Goodsell Wolcott7 (Thomas Goodsell Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 19 MAR 1790 North Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 1822 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesSARAH wrote poetry and played the guitar. Her sister, Eliza, wrote "The Two Sisters, Poems and Memories", published by Baldway & Stradway, New Haven, 1830, containing many of Sarah's poems. She and her husband moved to Southwick, Massachusetts after their marriage. After his death she returned to her parents' home with her son and had a school.

(6) Lydia Austin6 (Lydia Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 DEC 1764 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 28 APR 1829 .
NotesLYDIA made a statement at Rockville on 13 Aug, 1842, stating she was born New Haven 9 Dec. 1764, daughter of Samuel Austin and of a daughter of Dr. Alexander Wolcott, that she was under the ministry of Dr. Jonathan Edwards until age 26 at the time of her marriage to Rev. David Hale of Lisbon. In 1804 due to her husband's health he was dismissed and they moved to Coventry. He died in 1822,

(7) David Hale7 (Lydia Austin6, Lydia Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 25 APR 1791 Lisbon, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 20 JAN 1849 Fredericksburg, Spotsylvania Co., Virginia.

Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
2 children.
(4) Alexander Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 JAN 1712 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1795 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale in 1731 and "owned the Covenant" in 1733 at the First Church of New Haven. He studied medicine with Dr. Norman Morrison at Hartford, and accompanied his father as surgeon's mate in the expedition against Louisburg during the French and Indian Wars. He settled in Windsor, where he was a practicing physician from 1740 until the 1780s. He served as Justice of the Peace and Representative of the town to the General Assembly. He succeeded his brother, Roger, as a member of the Susquehanna Land Company, of which he was a member in 1774 and 1786. He was appointed Chairman of the Windsor Committee of Safety and was head of a commission to examine applicants for becoming surgeons in the Continental Army. For his services during the war, he was awarded land at Montgomery, Franklin Co., New Hampshire. Alexander wrote poetry, some of which was published. He owned a slave named Primus who assisted him in his medical work. Primus was freed by Alexander and was known as Dr. Primus Manumit, with his own medical practice. In the 1790 census, Alexander had 1 male over 16, 3 males under 16, 2 females, and 2 free Negros living in his home at Windsor. Alexander's home, built in 1745, stood at the top of the Broad St. Green in downtown Windsor. It was moved to make room for building that is now Arthurs Drug Store. It is now at 5 Moorlands St. in Windsor. It has a huge double fireplace, a birthing room, and a 5 ft. wide vat in the attic made from one huge tree.

In the case Alexander Walcott et al. v. James Swan et al., April 1800, an appeal from the Court of Chancery, where Swan and Alexander McRae sued Walcott, Smyth and Price, saying that on 21 July 1795 they entered into contract regarding lands in Russell County whereby McRae gave Smyth, the registrar of the land office, land warrants for 300,000 acres of land in Russel County. After this Walcott gave Smyth a considerable sum of money for which Smyth gave him the warrants for which Walcott took lands in Lee County of inferior value. These lands were included in a 650,000 acre survey made for Walcott and returned to Smyth who was to issue a patent to Walcott. The suit was to enjoin Smyth from issuing the patent to Walcott and to issue 300,000 acres to Swan, or that pary of the survey orininally entered on warrents of Swan. Alexander Walcott said that in June 1795 he, David Booth and Austin Nichols of Connecticut were in Montgomery Co., Virginia, and met with Smyth who proposed to survey for them a tract on the Big Sandy River. Walcott, Booth and Nichols were to return to Connecticut and secure the mone and meet Smyth on 20 Sep. following in Richmond and Smyth was to hold the said lands for them until then. They raise sufficient money to secure 1,500,000 acres of land and returned on 20 Sept to find Smyth gone, at which time Booth and Nichols relinquished to Walcott their rights to the contract. Smyth in the meantime had issued 300,000 to Swan, but later surveyed for Swan the better land in Lee County and for Walcott 650,00 acres in Russell County. Alexander Walcott was required to assign to James Swan 3000,000 of the 650,000 acres.
1797 land grant to Alexander Wolcott of 50,000 acres in Lee Co. Virginia by Gov. James Wood
In 1807 Diggs and Keith sued Alexander Wolcott in Middlesex C. Connecticut courts for promissory notes given by him for the purchase of land in Virginia.
1822 receipt to Alexander Wolcott for redemption of land returned delinquent by the sheriff of Lee Co. Virginia.
m. 17 MAR 1739 Mary Mansfield, b. 23 FEB 1707 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 1741 .
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(4) Alexander Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 JAN 1712 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1795 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale in 1731 and "owned the Covenant" in 1733 at the First Church of New Haven. He studied medicine with Dr. Norman Morrison at Hartford, and accompanied his father as surgeon's mate in the expedition against Louisburg during the French and Indian Wars. He settled in Windsor, where he was a practicing physician from 1740 until the 1780s. He served as Justice of the Peace and Representative of the town to the General Assembly. He succeeded his brother, Roger, as a member of the Susquehanna Land Company, of which he was a member in 1774 and 1786. He was appointed Chairman of the Windsor Committee of Safety and was head of a commission to examine applicants for becoming surgeons in the Continental Army. For his services during the war, he was awarded land at Montgomery, Franklin Co., New Hampshire. Alexander wrote poetry, some of which was published. He owned a slave named Primus who assisted him in his medical work. Primus was freed by Alexander and was known as Dr. Primus Manumit, with his own medical practice. In the 1790 census, Alexander had 1 male over 16, 3 males under 16, 2 females, and 2 free Negros living in his home at Windsor. Alexander's home, built in 1745, stood at the top of the Broad St. Green in downtown Windsor. It was moved to make room for building that is now Arthurs Drug Store. It is now at 5 Moorlands St. in Windsor. It has a huge double fireplace, a birthing room, and a 5 ft. wide vat in the attic made from one huge tree.

In the case Alexander Walcott et al. v. James Swan et al., April 1800, an appeal from the Court of Chancery, where Swan and Alexander McRae sued Walcott, Smyth and Price, saying that on 21 July 1795 they entered into contract regarding lands in Russell County whereby McRae gave Smyth, the registrar of the land office, land warrants for 300,000 acres of land in Russel County. After this Walcott gave Smyth a considerable sum of money for which Smyth gave him the warrants for which Walcott took lands in Lee County of inferior value. These lands were included in a 650,000 acre survey made for Walcott and returned to Smyth who was to issue a patent to Walcott. The suit was to enjoin Smyth from issuing the patent to Walcott and to issue 300,000 acres to Swan, or that pary of the survey orininally entered on warrents of Swan. Alexander Walcott said that in June 1795 he, David Booth and Austin Nichols of Connecticut were in Montgomery Co., Virginia, and met with Smyth who proposed to survey for them a tract on the Big Sandy River. Walcott, Booth and Nichols were to return to Connecticut and secure the mone and meet Smyth on 20 Sep. following in Richmond and Smyth was to hold the said lands for them until then. They raise sufficient money to secure 1,500,000 acres of land and returned on 20 Sept to find Smyth gone, at which time Booth and Nichols relinquished to Walcott their rights to the contract. Smyth in the meantime had issued 300,000 to Swan, but later surveyed for Swan the better land in Lee County and for Walcott 650,00 acres in Russell County. Alexander Walcott was required to assign to James Swan 3000,000 of the 650,000 acres.
1797 land grant to Alexander Wolcott of 50,000 acres in Lee Co. Virginia by Gov. James Wood
In 1807 Diggs and Keith sued Alexander Wolcott in Middlesex C. Connecticut courts for promissory notes given by him for the purchase of land in Virginia.
1822 receipt to Alexander Wolcott for redemption of land returned delinquent by the sheriff of Lee Co. Virginia.

(5) Esther Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 17 SEP 1746 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 9 OCT 1746 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.

(5) Simon Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 AUG 1747 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 APR 1809 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesSIMON was a physician at New London, Connecticut. For several years he was Secretary of the County Medical Society. He served a surgeon of the 6th Connecticut Regiment during the Revolutionary War from 20 May 1775 until 21 December 1775 and in Col. Guy's Regiment from June to December 1776. His house and barn on "The Bank" at New London, were burned by the British during the war. In 1791 he was compensated for loss of property at New London , valued at 1,083L, by a grant of land in the Western Reserve of Ohio. In 1790 his family at New London consisted of 2 males over 16, 1 male under 16, and 8 females.
m. 23 JAN 1774 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Lucy Rogers, b. 1752 , d. 21 APR 1791 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 27 nodes.
8 children: Lucretia, Alexander, Lucy, Mary, Lucy, Charlotte, Catherine, Elizabeth.
(6) Lucretia Wolcott6 (Simon Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 24 JAN 1775 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 21 MAR 1823 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
m. 28 OCT 1793 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Richard Law, b. 6 MAR 1763 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 19 OCT 1845 .
Spouse NotesRICHARD was a Navy Captain during the Revolutionary War.
Subtree size: 2 nodes.
1 child: Mary Cecelia.

(6) Alexander Wolcott6 (Simon Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 12 NOV 1775 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. at Sea.
NotesALEXANDER died at sea.

Subtree size: 2 nodes.
1 child: Alexander Simon.
(7) Alexander Simon Wolcott7 (Alexander Wolcott6, Simon Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1805 ,, New York, d. 10 NOV 1844 Stamford, Fairfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER was listed as an artist in New York City in 1841, and was said to have been known for his mechanical ingenuity. He was a pioneer in amateur Deguerreotype photography, working with John Johnson to create a daguerreotype camera in 1839. After the camera was patented in 1840, he traveled to Washington, D. C. and helped Stevenson open a gallery there, and in 1841 went to London to show the invention. The "New York Times" of 28 Jan 1883 stated, "Mr. A. S. Wolcott, who was for a long time in the business of daguerreotyping in this city, and afterwards opened a laboratory in London, really preceded Prof. Draper by several weeks in the application of Daguerre's discovery..., to whom may be ascribed the first image of the human face ever taken by sunlight." The question of whether Wolcott or Draper took the first photograph of a living person was hotly disputed. Alexander purchased property at Stamford, Connecticut, in 1842 and had a rolling mill there. His obituary in the Stamford Advocate reads: "Died in this village on Sunday last, of consumption, Mr. Alexander Simon Wolcott, aged 40 years." His will was probated inthe Stamford, Connecticut, court: "Wolcott, Alexander S., deceased, late of Stamford, Nov. 13 1844, his widow refused to qualify...." This record mentions Cynthia L. Wolcott, age 13, who had Humphrey Phelps of New York City appointed as her guardian. Humphrey Phelps was apparently the one who was a New York City publisher of prints and maps, 1832-53, author of "Pictorial View of the World" published New York City 1847 and "Phelps Travelers' Guides" of various cities which were published beginning in 1838.
m. 1832 Bridgeport, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, Mary Sanborn, b. 10 APR 1809 New Hampton, Belknap Co., New Hampshire, d. 20 JUL 1895 New Hampton, Belknap Co., New Hampshire.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
1 child.

NotesSIMON was a physician at New London, Connecticut. For several years he was Secretary of the County Medical Society. He served a surgeon of the 6th Connecticut Regiment during the Revolutionary War from 20 May 1775 until 21 December 1775 and in Col. Guy's Regiment from June to December 1776. His house and barn on "The Bank" at New London, were burned by the British during the war. In 1791 he was compensated for loss of property at New London , valued at 1,083L, by a grant of land in the Western Reserve of Ohio. In 1790 his family at New London consisted of 2 males over 16, 1 male under 16, and 8 females.

(5) George Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 17 OCT 1753 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 31 JAN 1822 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesGEORGE was a Representative for the town of Windsor at the General Assembly. In 1790, his family at Windsor consisted of 3 males over 16, 2 males under 16, and 5 females. He moved to Saybrook, Connecticut, in 1804, where he was Surveyor of the Port.

(5) Christopher Drake Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1 OCT 1754 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 APR 1821 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesCHRISTOPHER studied medicine with his father. He was a surgeon's mate in Col. Erastus Wolcott's regiment from December 1775 to January 1781 during the Revolutionary War. He was granted land at Enosburg, Franklin County, New Hampshire, for his military service. He was a physician at Windsor, Connecticut, one of the founders of the Hartford County Medical Society, and served as a Representative to the General Assembly. He lived in his father's house after his father's death. In 1790 he was at Windsor with a family of 3 males over 16, 2 males under 16, and 5 females.
m. 1 AUG 1782 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Lucy Parsons, b. 3 AUG 1762 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 MAR 1804 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 31 nodes.
6 children: Laura, Elizabeth, Christopher Columbus, Laura, Elizabeth, Philip.
(6) Laura Wolcott6 (Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 MAY 1783 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 AUG 1789 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(6) Elizabeth Wolcott6 (Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 20 JAN 1785 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 MAY 1786 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(6) Christopher Columbus Wolcott6 (Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 JUN 1787 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 18 DEC 1853 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
NotesCHRISTOPHER lived at Wolcottville, Connecticut, where he was a Justice of the Peace and Representative to the Connecticut State Legislature. In 1833 he moved to Steubenville, Ohio, where he engaged in woolen manufacturing. He was a visitor at the Steubenville Female Seminary where his daughter, Caroline, was a student, in 1836-7. The 1837 business directory for Beaver Co., Pennsylvania, has at Fallston: "C. C. Wolcott has a large factory for the manufacturing of Jeans upon a very extensive scale with splendid machinery, unsurpassed for excellency and beauty by any in any part of the country." He operated the Fallston factory until 1850 or later.
m. 18 NOV 1818 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, Susan Blinn, b. 14 AUG 1795 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 10 APR 1859 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
Subtree size: 8 nodes.
7 children: Christopher Parsons, Samuel Merwin, Henry Philip "Harry", Frederick Halsey, Susan Maria, Caroline Matilda, Laura Elizabeth.
(7) Christopher Parsons Wolcott7 (Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 17 DEC 1820 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 4 APR 1863 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesCHRISTOPHER attended Kenyon College in 1839, and graduated from Jefferson College at Washington, Pennsylvania, in 1840 at the age of 20. He read law in the office of Tappan & Stanton. Tappan became U. S. Senator from Ohio, and Edwin Stanton became Secretary of War. Christopher was admitted to the Bar in 1843, and established a law practice at Akron in 1846. He built a large home on West Market St. in Akron, which was destroyed by fire in 1933. He was appointed Attorney-General for the State of Ohio in 1856 and served until 1861. His most famous case was the Wellington Fugitive Slave case. He journied to Virginia to ask Gov. Wise to spare the life of the abolitionist, John Brown, whose home was at Kent, Portage Co., Ohio. He became Judge Advocate General in 1861. In May of 1862 he was appointed Assistant Secretary of War, under his brother-in-law, Edwin Stanton, Secretary of War. He held this position at the time of his death. His brother-in-law often visited his widowed sister at Gambier to rest from his greuling schedule, He was so unobtrusive that the neighbors usually did not know he was there. When his two nephews, Darwin and Merwin, were in College after the war, Stanton spoke affectionately of his college days at Kenyon College from which he received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree..
m. 18 APR 1844 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, Pamphila Stanton, b. 20 FEB 1827 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 8 FEB 1899 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesPAMPHILA was living with her son, Darwin, in Washington, D. C., in 1880.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
5 children.
