(7) Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott7 (Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 4 FEB 1824 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 11 MAY 1868 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
NotesHENRY P. Wolcott of Steubenville, Ohio, attended the Western Reserve College 1840-41. He was a woolen manufacturer at Steubenville, Ohio, in 1850. He was at Steubenville, Ohio, in 1860, with Sarah, Susan, Harry, Laura, Jessie, and Carrie. Jessie Wolcott Cool is married inthe same cemetery lot.
m. 26 JAN 1847 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, Sarah Ann Allen, b. 22 FEB 1827 Ravenna, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 1904 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesSARAH was at Steubebville, Ohio, in 1870, with Laura, Jessie, and Carrie. She and her children, Jesse and Carrie, were living at Steubenville in 1880. In 1900 she lived with her daughter, Laura. Ann and Thomas Allen, possibly her parents, are buried in the same cemetery lot.

(7) John Randolph Marshall7 (Elizabeth Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 6 JUL 1822 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 11 JUL 1891 Dublin, Franklin Co., Ohio.
NotesJOHN was one of the first Doctors in Dublin, Ohio. He served as an officer in the Mexican War in 1846, in Company I, 3rd Regiment, Ohio Volunteer Infantry Regt. He was an Ohio state representative, and a contributor to the Columbus Record. He is said to have discovered a cure for black diptheria and for cholera. In 1998 his doctors office was still standing.
m. 29 AUG 1852 Worthington, Franklin Co., Ohio, Louise Marie Lusk, b. 18 AUG 1832 Worthington, Franklin Co., Ohio, d. 11 JUN 1873 Dublin, Franklin Co., Ohio.

(7) Lucy Ann Marshall7 (Elizabeth Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 14 NOV 1827 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1903 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 25 NOV 1850 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Ellsworth Newberry Phelps, b. 9 FEB 1826 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. JAN 1913 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesELLSWORTH enlisted in Co. A, 22nd Connecticut Inf. Regt. in 1862, and was elected Captain of the company. He recruited 130 men and was appointed Lt. Col. of the Regt. He was a Whig and later a Republican, an Episcopalian, justice of the peace, and grand juror. He was assistant civil engineer on the Connecticut River, surveying much of Hartford County. He also had a farm.

(5) Christopher Drake Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1 OCT 1754 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 APR 1821 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesCHRISTOPHER studied medicine with his father. He was a surgeon's mate in Col. Erastus Wolcott's regiment from December 1775 to January 1781 during the Revolutionary War. He was granted land at Enosburg, Franklin County, New Hampshire, for his military service. He was a physician at Windsor, Connecticut, one of the founders of the Hartford County Medical Society, and served as a Representative to the General Assembly. He lived in his father's house after his father's death. In 1790 he was at Windsor with a family of 3 males over 16, 2 males under 16, and 5 females.

1 child.
(5) Alexander Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 15 SEP 1758 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 26 JUN 1828 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale College in 1778 and practiced law in Windsor, where he was a Representative to the General Assembly for five sessions, 1796-1801. He was a member of the Susquehanna Land Company in 1786. He had warrant of 50,000 acres on south side of Powell's Muntain on Guest's River, and 100,000 acres on the west bank of Tottery Creek in 1795. In 1796 he sold a grant of 100,000 acres on the East Branch of the Big Sandy River in Russell Co., Virginia, to Ebenezer Fitch Bissell. In 1799 he held 12,500 acres of land in Grayson Co., Virginia. His land holding claims were disputed due to disagreements between Virginia and Kentucky over their borders, and "Wolcotters" became a term for people with dubious land claims. Alexander Smyth of Wythe Co., Virginia, contracted with Alexander Wolcott of Connecticut to survey 850,000 acres of land. An 1800 deed conveyed 1,034 acres of land from Alexander Smyth to Alexander Wolcott of Windsor, Connecticut, for 434 dollars. Alexander was at Middleton, Connecticut in 1800, were he was a Justice of the Peace. He was Collector of Customs for Middletown there from 1801 until his death in 1828, when he was succeeded by his eldest son. He was one of the early manufacturers of woolen cloth in this country. Alexander was one of the leaders of the Republican Party of Connecticut. He was nominated for the U.S. Supreme Court by President Madison in 1810, but the nomination failed to get the approval of the Senate for political reasons, 24 to 9. It was said "But he was widely unpopular as revenue collectors tend to be". He was a member of the State Constitutional Convention in 1818.
m. 22 SEP 1785 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Frances Burbank, b. 1765 Springfield, Hampshire, after 1812 Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 17 JAN 1800 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 26 nodes.
4 children: Frances, Henry, Alexander, Mary Ann.
(6) Frances Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 AUG 1786 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. AFT 1835 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
m. 2 MAR 1804 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, Thomas Homans, b. ABT 1780 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 1805 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
Subtree size: 2 nodes.
1 child: Frances.
(7) Frances Homans7 (Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. ABT 1804 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. ABT 1865 .
Subtree size: 1 node.

(6) Frances Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 AUG 1786 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. AFT 1835 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
m. 5 JAN 1806 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, Arthur William Magill, b. 3 AUG 1783 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 1855 Ottawa, LaSalle Co., Illinois.
Subtree size: 8 nodes.
7 children: Juliette Augusta, William A., Mary Ann Wolcott, Arthur, Henry Wolcott, Alexander Wolcot, Julian.
(7) Juliette Augusta Magill7 (Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 11 SEP 1806 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 17 SEP 1870 Amagansett, Suffolk Co., New York.
NotesJULIETTE was called "Chicago's First Author". She attended Emma Willard's Scholl at Troy, New York, and her uncle, Alexander Wolcott, taught her Latin and other languages. She accompanied her husband into the wilderness of Wisconsin, Michigan, and Illinois. Her best known book, published in 1856, was entitled "Waubun, the Early Days in the Northwest". It was a story of her experiences living in the wilderness from 1830 to 1833.
m. 9 AUG 1827 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York, John Harris Kinzie, b. 7 JUL 1803 Sandwich,, Canada, d. 21 JUN 1865 Pittsburgh, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania.
Spouse NotesJOHN came with his father to what is now Chicago, in 1803. They were among the first settlers there. John moved to Detroit, Michiigan in 1816, and was appointed Indian Agent for the Winnebagos there in 1828. From 1830 to 1833, he travelled throught Wisconsin, Michigan, and Illinois, distributing blankets, cloth, guns, Kettles, traps, and other things to the Indians as a representative of the U.S. government. He signed as a witness to a treaty between the U. S. government and the Chippewa Indian Nation in 1833, and is listed in an attachment to the treaty as rustee for money owed under the treaty to Jean Bt. Miranda, Jane Miranda, Rosetta Miranda, and Thomas Miranda, and for Josett Ouilmot. In another attachment to the treaty, John H. Kinzie and Ellen M. Wolcott were named as owed $5,000 each. On returning to Chicago in 1834, he became President of the Board of Trustees of the village. He was appointed Registrar of Public Lands at Chicago in 1841, and Paymaster of the U.S. Army in 1861. In 1865 he was brevetted Lt. Colonel in the U.S. Army. He built the First Episcopal Church in Chicago.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.

(6) Henry Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 6 MAR 1788 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 5 APR 1846 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesHENRY was a physician. He was a Justice of the Peace and was appointed Collector of the Port at Middleton in 1828. In 1833, he moved to Chicago, Illinois, where he practiced medicine. Henry Wolcott had a private boarding house at Wolcott and Kinzie Streets in Chicago, in 1839.
m. 6 NOV 1813 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, Mary Almira Starr, b. 2 MAR 1795 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 30 MAR 1870 .
Subtree size: 10 nodes.
9 children: Alexander, Henry Huntington, Caroline Starr, Edward, Frances Burbank, Ellen, Almira, Emma, Juliette.
(7) Alexander Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 OCT 1814 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 11 AUG 1884 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesALEXANDER may have been the Alex Walcott, age 35, who was an engineer at Yuba City, California, in 1850. He was Cook County Surveyor in 1868. He was a surveyor at Chicago, Ilinois, in 1880.
m. 25 DEC 1845 , Dupage Co., Illinois, Mary A. Spaulding, b. 1817 ,, Massachusetts, d. 28 AUG 1909 , Cook Co., Illinois.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
3 children.
(7) Henry Huntington Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 5 AUG 1816 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 28 SEP 1890 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York.
NotesHENRYmoved to Chicago in 1832 with his brother, Alexander. They lived with the family of his cousin, Mrs. John Kinzie. Henry Huntington Wolcott of Racine Co., Wisconsin, purchased 160 acres of government land at Racine Co. in 1843. He was listed as H. H. Wolcott in the 1844 city directory of Chicago, as clerk at Humphries & Winslow's, and residing at the City Hotel, and/or the Henry Wolcott, clerk at the post office and resident at the City Hotel. He was later in the transportation business on the Great Lakes and the Illinois and Michigan Canal. In 1859 returned to the East where he and his childhood friend, Eben Townsend Starr, and others formed the Starr Arms Company at Lowell, Massachusetts. Henry was a major investor and President of the company, which moved to Binghampton, and finally to Yonkers, New York. Henry and Eben Townsend grew up together at Middletown, Connecticut, and shared a great-grandfather, Jehosaphat Starr. They established an armory at Yonkers, New York. Henry held several patents for inventions connected with guns. Their company manufactured arms for the Union Army during the Civil War. In 1860 it accepted a contract for 12,000 pistols, then another 8,000 and 10,000 breech loading carbines.They had armories at Binghampton and Yonkers. After the war, they sold surplus arms to foreign governments. In 1880 Henry was a paper box manufacturer in New York City. Henry's son, Townsend, was named after Eben Starr and was the Executor of Eben's estate in 1899. His obituary said he was survived by his wife, two sons, and a daughter. Research on Henry and Eben Starr is being done by Robin Eichleay, P. O. Box 49297, Los Angeles CA 90049, 612 860-2783
m. 13 OCT 1852 Niagara Falls, Niagara Co., New York, Elizabeth Franklin Townsend, b. 21 NOV 1820 Goshen, Orange Co., New York, d. 10 JUL 1896 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
5 children.
(7) Caroline Starr Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 8 OCT 1818 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 1901 .
m. 19 JUN 1837 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, Joseph Neree Balestier, b. 1 APR 1814 Martinique, West Indies, d. 1888 Arlington, Bennington Co., Vermont.
Spouse NotesJOSEPH was schooled by his brother's sister-in-law, Harriet Revere, daughter of Paul Revere. He then studied law. In 1835 he moved to Chicago where he practiced law for 7 years. He was a delegate to the convention that nominated Abraham Lincoln for President. In 1842 the Balestiers moved to New York City, where he was senior partner in the law firm, Balestier & Lane. He retired to his home, "Beechwood, in Vermont, where he died.

NotesEDWARD was a school teacher in Glenn, Montgomery Co., New York. In 1880 he and his wife were living in a hotel at Washington, D.C.

(7) Juliette Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 20 NOV 1835 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 8 AUG 1836 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.

0 children.
(6) Alexander Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 14 FEB 1790 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 NOV 1830 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale College in 1807. He subsequently studied medicine with Dr. Nathan Smith at Hanover, New Hampshire. He enlisted 25 May 1812 and was commissioned Surgeon's Mate in the U.S. Army, stationed at Ft. Moultrie, South Carolina, and Governors Island. After the war he established himself as a physician at Vincennes, Indiana. Alexander was appointed Indian Agent at Detroit in 1819, and accompanied Gov. Lewis Cass on his exploration of Lake Superior and the Mississippi headwaters in 1820. He was appointed Indian Agent at Chicago in 1820. His residence in Chicago was call "Cobweb Castle", and he lived there until his marriage in 1823. It was the first wedding in Chicago. He was also a Justice of the Peace. In 1830 he purchased for 600 dollars 8 lots in Chicago. His land is now the site of the Marina City Towers complex. His widow inherited his property and deeded these lands to David Hunter. On the 1830 census he is recorded at Fort Dearborn as a family with Alexander 40-50, 1 male 20-30, 1 male 10-15, 1 male 5-10, and 5 females age 60-70, Eleanor 30-40, 20-30, 15-20, 10-15, and 5-10, the elder woman probably his mother-in-law. His will left his property to his wife and his daughter, Mary Ann, his only living child.
m. 20 JUL 1823 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, Eleanor Marion Kinzie, b. DEC 1804 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 1 AUG 1849 Detroit, Wayne Co., Michigan.
Spouse NotesELEANOR was the first white child born in Chicago, Illinois.
Subtree size: 4 nodes.
3 children: Mary Ann, Ellen Maria, Alexander.

(6) Mary Ann Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 11 FEB 1792 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 SEP 1865 .

(5) Alexander Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 15 SEP 1758 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 26 JUN 1828 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale College in 1778 and practiced law in Windsor, where he was a Representative to the General Assembly for five sessions, 1796-1801. He was a member of the Susquehanna Land Company in 1786. He had warrant of 50,000 acres on south side of Powell's Muntain on Guest's River, and 100,000 acres on the west bank of Tottery Creek in 1795. In 1796 he sold a grant of 100,000 acres on the East Branch of the Big Sandy River in Russell Co., Virginia, to Ebenezer Fitch Bissell. In 1799 he held 12,500 acres of land in Grayson Co., Virginia. His land holding claims were disputed due to disagreements between Virginia and Kentucky over their borders, and "Wolcotters" became a term for people with dubious land claims. Alexander Smyth of Wythe Co., Virginia, contracted with Alexander Wolcott of Connecticut to survey 850,000 acres of land. An 1800 deed conveyed 1,034 acres of land from Alexander Smyth to Alexander Wolcott of Windsor, Connecticut, for 434 dollars. Alexander was at Middleton, Connecticut in 1800, were he was a Justice of the Peace. He was Collector of Customs for Middletown there from 1801 until his death in 1828, when he was succeeded by his eldest son. He was one of the early manufacturers of woolen cloth in this country. Alexander was one of the leaders of the Republican Party of Connecticut. He was nominated for the U.S. Supreme Court by President Madison in 1810, but the nomination failed to get the approval of the Senate for political reasons, 24 to 9. It was said "But he was widely unpopular as revenue collectors tend to be". He was a member of the State Constitutional Convention in 1818.
m. 7 JUN 1807 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Lucy Waldo, b. 10 AUG 1766 Falmouth, Cumberland Co., Maine, d. 10 SEP 1839 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(5) Guy Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 AUG 1760 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 SEP 1823 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio.
NotesGUY was at Litchfield Co., Connecticut in 1790, with a family of 2 males under 16, 2 males over 16, and 2 females. He settled at Torrington, Connecticut, in 1783, on a farm a mile and a half west of what became Wolcottville. The name was given the town by popular vote after Guy and Frederick Wolcott built a woolen mill on the Waterbury River there in 1813. Guy was elected deacon of the Torrington church in 1821. The mill ran into financial difficulties, and in 1822 Guy moved to Tallmadge, Ohio, where his eldest son had settled a few years earlier. Tallmadge was in Portage County until 1840 when Summit County was created. Guy and his wife, Abigail, were 3rd cousins.
m. 5 OCT 1781 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Abigail Allyn, b. 5 OCT 1765 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 21 FEB 1836 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio.
Subtree size: 72 nodes.
13 children: , Abigail, Abigail, Guy, James, Elizur "Eli", Frederick, Anna, Almira, Amanda, Eleanor, George, Allyn Ellsworth.
(6) Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1782 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 12 FEB 1782 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(6) Abigail Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 13 FEB 1784 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 1784 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(6) Abigail Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 2 JUL 1785 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 3 AUG 1830 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio.
m. 26 MAY 1803 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, Nathan Gillett, b. 7 MAR 1781 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. Middlebury, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesNATHAN Gillett Jr. becamea freeman of Torrington CT in 1802. Moved to Western Reserve 1817.
Subtree size: 12 nodes.
10 children: Eliza M., Catharine Wolcott, Charlotte, Lucretia, Alexander Wolcott, Mary Ann, Amanda, Abigail "Abby", Annis, Oliver Wolcott.
(7) Eliza M. Gillett7 (Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1804 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 12 SEP 1846 .
m. 15 OCT 1820 Titus Chapman, b. 23 APR 1793 , Rutland Co., Vermont, d. 30 JUN 1866 .
Spouse NotesTITUS' family moved to Trumbull Co., Ohio, in 1806. The area became Summit Co. He served in the War of 1812. He was a farmer at Tallmadge Township, Ohio, in 1850, with wife Sophia. The Chapman family, or the descendants of Robert Chapman, one of the first settlers of Say-Brook, Conn., with genealogical notes of William Chapman, who settled in New London, Conn.; Edward Chapman, who settled at Windsor, Conn.; John Chapman, of Stonington, Conn.; and Rev. Benjamin Chapman, of Southington, Conn., by F. W. Chapman (Hartford: Case, Tiffany and Co., 1854), p. 217, 242-243
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
2 children.
(7) Catharine Wolcott Gillett7 (Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 NOV 1805 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. FEB 1879 , Fulton Co., Ohio.
NotesCATHERINE moved to Summit Co. with her parents.
m. 16 JUN 1825 , Summit Co., Ohio, John Nash, b. 11 AUG 1796 Egremont, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts, d. 30 AUG 1852 Middlebury, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesJOHN was a carpenter. He moved to Utica, New York, and then to Summit Co., Ohio. The Nash family, or records of the descendants of Thomas Nash of New Haven, Connecticut, 1640, by Sylvester Nash (Hartford: Case, Tiffany and Co., 1853), p. 246

(7) Lucretia Gillett7 (Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 10 SEP 1809 ,, Connecticut, d. 1881 Connellsville, Fayette Co., Pennsylvania.
m. 26 SEP 1827 ,, Ohio, Alfred Whitter, b. 10 AUG 1800 Washington, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts, d. 1892 Connellsville, Fayette Co., Pennsylvania.

Information about his family is from "History of Torrington, Connecticut, from its first settlement in 1737, with biographies and genealogies", by Samuel Orcutt (Albany: J. (6) Guy Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 13 OCT 1787 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 2 DEC 1865 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesGUY bought one-eighth interest in the Wilsons Sawmill Company in 1811. In 1817 he moved from Wolcottville, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, to Portage County, Ohio, where he bought a large farm in Tallmadge Township. Tallmadge became part of Summit County in 1840, but part of it is still in Portage County.
m. 24 APR 1821 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Annis "Annie" Porter, b. 12 NOV 1801 Waterbury, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 2 FEB 1882 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesANNIS' family moved to Talmadge, Ohio, in 1817. She lived with her daughter, Charlotte, in 1880.
Subtree size: 10 nodes.
8 children: James Orin, Elizabeth Elvira, Charlotte Amanda, Lemuel Porter, Elizur V., Eleanor, Franklin Maginnis "Frank", Ellen Coe.
(7) James Orin Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 5 APR 1823 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 29 DEC 1876 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesJames inherited his father's homestead and half of the farm at Tallmadge. The other half of the farm went to his brother, Lemuel. He was at Tallmadge in 1860, with Ellen, Elizabeth, Jane, Judson, and Waldo Wolcott.
m. 4 NOV 1846 Jane E. Lewis, b. 27 JUN 1826 Portland, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 8 FEB 1850 Northampton, Summit Co., Ohio.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
2 children.
(7) James Orin Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 5 APR 1823 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 29 DEC 1876 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesJames inherited his father's homestead and half of the farm at Tallmadge. The other half of the farm went to his brother, Lemuel. He was at Tallmadge in 1860, with Ellen, Elizabeth, Jane, Judson, and Waldo Wolcott.
m. 26 JUN 1850 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Ellen A. Lewis, b. 16 AUG 1831 Portland, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 6 JAN 1921 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesELLEN came with her parents to Northampton, Ohio, when she was 7. In 1880 she was at Tallmadge, Ohio, with Elizabeth E., Jennie E., Waldo W., and Mary E. Wolcott. Lemuel P. Porter who later married her daughter, was living with the family. Ellen was active in the Congregational church.

(7) Elizabeth Elvira Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 25 MAY 1824 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 14 MAY 1845 South Hadley, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts.
NotesEMILY died at Mt. Holyoke Seminary at age 21. She was in her last year in the seminary.

(7) Charlotte Amanda Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 3 SEP 1827 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 19 MAY 1891 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
m. 12 OCT 1851 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Dennis Edson Fenn, b. 16 MAR 1828 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 8 MAY 1901 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesDennis was a dentist and farmer at Tallmadge. In 1852, he purchased a 215 acre farm where he lived the rest of his life. In 1861, he began the study of dentistry and opened an office at Tallmadge. He was a member of the Tallmadge Congregational Church.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
4 children.
(7) Lemuel Porter Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 18 AUG 1831 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 10 NOV 1876 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesLEMUEL was a life-long farmer in Tallmadge, Ohio. His father split the family farm between Lemuel and his brother, James. James retained the original homestead while Lemuel built a new house in 1856 which remained in the Wolcott family for five generations. Lemuel and James attended the nation's Centennial celebration in Philadelphia in 1876, caught a disease there and both came home to die later that year. The following sketch appears in History of Summit County, by William Henry Perrin, printed in 1881): "Harriet E. Treat, farmer; P. O. Tallmadge; is the widow of Lemuel P. Walcott, who was born in Tallmadge Aug. 18, 1831; his childhood was passed on the farm, where he remained until he had grown to manhood; he obtained his education in the common schools, the Windom Academy and the Nelson High School; after completing his education, he returned to the farm, and there lived until it was divided between himself and brothers. In November, 1856, he married Harriet E., daughter of Richard and Amoret Treat, who shared his happiness until death separated them; he died Nov. 10, 1876, at the age of 45 years; he was a man much missed in the surrounding community in which he lived, for his amiable disposition, gentlemanly bearing and devotion to his church....".
m. 2 NOV 1856 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Harriet Esther Treat, b. 9 SEP 1831 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 5 SEP 1921 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesThe Treat Family: A genealogy of Trott, Tratt, and Treat for fifteen generations, and four hundred and fifty years in England and America ..., by John Harvey Treat (Salem, MA: Salem Press, 1893), p. 387, 457
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
3 children.
(7) Elizur V. Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 14 JUL 1833 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 20 DEC 1873 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesELIZUR was a student at the Western Reserve College in 1850, and graduated from Yale in 1854. He became a tutor at Western Reserve College in 1856. In 1857 he entered Andover Theological Seminary. Due to failing health he left the seminary before completing his studies. He bought the Pierce farm, and live there until his death. In 1870 he was at Tallmadge, Ohio, with Clara P., and Byron and his mother, Annie Wolcott.
m. 29 NOV 1860 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Fannie L. Pierce, b. 1834 Woodbury, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 23 SEP 1906 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesFANNY P. Wolcott was Tallmadge, Ohio, in 1880, with Clara P., Kate E., Emily P., and Josephine M. Wolcott. Her mother, Jan P. Sackett, was living with her. Her second husband was minister at Tallmadge at the time her husband died.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
4 children.
(7) Eleanor Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 14 JUL 1833 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 14 JUL 1834 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 20 FEB 1837 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 8 MAY 1896 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska.
NotesFRANKLIN went to Nebraska in 1856. He took up 160 acres of land in Center Precinct, where he engaged in real estate and loaning money for 7 years. He returned to Ohio in 1862, and married. He purchased 220 acres of land near Weeping Water in 1864. In the fall of 1864 he moved West, shipping some sheep and cattle to Ottumwa, Iowa, where the railroad then ended. He drove the livestock overland, while his new wife continued by stage coach to the Missouri River. They crossed the river to Patsmouth on a flatboat. Then continue on to Nebraska, and lived in the second floor of the log cabin of Philander Beardsley, in Cass Co., a mile west of the present town of Weeping Water. They built a small log cabin, and a short time later built a frame house in front of it. He was elected to the Nebraska House of Representatives in 1870. Frank M. Wolcott was at Weeping Water in 1870, with wife Henrietta and daughters Lucy R. and Creda A. Wolcott. In 1880 Franklin became the county agent for the B & M Railroad Land Department Company in Cass and Otoe counties, showing the company's land grant lands to newly arrived pioneers and acting as real estate agent. In 1881 he was appointed notary public. Frank was instrumental in building the first church in Weeping Water. It later became the Weeping Water Academy, of which his daughter, Lucy, was in the second graduating class, in 1889. He died of a stroke while resting on a creek bank. His son, Lloyd, thought his father's middle name was Marshall, rather than Maginnis.
m. 10 MAY 1864 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Henrietta M. Brooks, b. 14 AUG 1845 New Rochelle, Westchester Co., New York, d. 16 FEB 1925 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska.
Spouse NotesHENRIETTA was sent to be raised by an aunt at Talmadge, Ohio, when her mother died. She joined the First Congregational Church at Weeping Water, Iowa in 1865. "My grandmother was so afraid of the Indians. She came as a young and sheltered girl to Nebraska, and was little prepared for the life on the frontier. As I remember it they were the second family to move to this neighborhood and formed the town of Weeping Water. There were few trees at the time and she often told how Mr. Wolcott went out and planted the maple trees that edged their property by lantern light. The Indians would come up from the creek where they camped to her cabin door and beg for food. They were not particularily dangerous in that neighborhood, but seemed so dirty and terrible. At that time Plattsmouth was the nearest town; twenty-two miles over the trails meant a two day journey for all provisions." - from granddaughter, Jeanette Teegarden.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
3 children.
(7) Ellen Coe Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 16 OCT 1844 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 5 APR 1871 .
NotesEllen was a graduate of Lake Erie Seminary.
m. 8 JUN 1870 Lyman Walker Peet, b. 14 JAN 1838 Cornwall, Addison Co., Vermont, d. 4 JAN 1917 Cornwall, Addison Co., Vermont.
Spouse NotesLYMAN attended Burr and Burton Seminary, and was a teacher at Tarrytown, New York, Hoboken, New Jersey, Nashville, Tennessee, Weeping Water, Nebraska, and Nebraska City 1861-77. He was a farmer at Cornwall 1877-1819. He served in the House of Representatives 1898-9. John Peet 1597-1684 of Stratford, Connecticut & his descendants, by Terry Charles Peet (Baltimore: Gateway Press, 1986), p. 87-88, 137
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(6) James Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 3 NOV 1789 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 5 JAN 1873 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesJAMES supervised the construction of a woolen mill on the Waterbury River for his father in 1813. In 1818 he moved to Delaware, Ohio, where he and Joseph S. Hughes constructed a woolen mill at Delaware, Ohio, which he managed fot two years. Here he joined the Episcopal church. He then moved to St. Louis, Missouri, where he married, and then settled at Fort Wayne, Indiana. He purchased 300 acres of land in Allen Co., Indiana in 1826 at Ft. Wayne. He and his wife and all their household goods were put in a boat and paddled down the Maumee River from Fort Wayne to Waynesfield, Ohio. In 1827 he purchased 300 acres of government land in Waynesfield Township for $1.25 an acre, and 377 acres in Lucas Co. He build a log house in what was then a wilderness and sold land to other settlers. In 1834-6 he built a two story frame house on the north bank of the river at Maumee in which he and his wife lived and died. He operated the Central House, Maumee's first "hotel" before establishing himself as a merchant. By 1837, his business, receiving and forwarding merchandise to Ft. Wayne and points west, was one of the largest in the area. He paid personal property taxes in Waynesfield Township in 1838. In 1838 he was elected to the first Maumee City Council, where he served as president. He also built wharves and shipyards along the river near his home. James commissioned construction of two steamboats, the "General Harrison", with a 150 ft. keel, launched in 1840, and the "James Wolcott". They operated between Maumee and Buffalo, New York, via Lake Erie. James was the first president of Maumee City Council in 1838. The following year he was elected Judge of the Lucas County Court of Common Pleas. In 1843 he was Mayor of Maumee. He was a founder of the Ohio Whig political party and a supporter of William Henry Harrison and Henry Clay. In 1860 he was at Maumee, with Fred K. and James Wolcott. James, William W., Eliza J., Zoe W., Byron, and James M. Wolcott were at Maumee in 1870. After his death, his home was occupied by his daughter Mary, and was willed to the Episcopal church about 1960. It is now a museum.
m. 8 MAR 1821 , St. Charles Co., Missouri, Mary Ann "Polly", "Ahmaquahzahquah" Wells, b. 10 MAY 1800 Fort Wayne, Allen Co., Indiana, d. 19 FEB 1843 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesMARY was the grand daughter of Chief Little Turtle of the Miami tribe. Her Indian name was "Ahmahquazahka".
Subtree size: 8 nodes.
7 children: William Wells, Robert Fulton, Mary Ann, Henry Clay, Frederick Calhoun "Fred", James Monroe "Tip", Emily B..
(7) William Wells Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 17 DEC 1821 Louisville, Jefferson Co., Kentucky, d. 30 APR 1905 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesWILLIAM came to Maumee, Ohio, in 1826 with his parents. As a young man, he intended to study law, but the death of his mother changed that plan. In 1840 he went to the Great Lakes where be became captain of some of the finest ships of those days. One of the boats he captained was the "General Harrison", built and owned by his father. He lived at Toledo OH from 1847 to 1850, and then moved back to Maumee, Ohio, where he was a general contractor of public works and a farmer. In 1860 he was at Maumee with Eliza, Effa, and Byron Wolcott. In 1880 he and his wife were living at Toledo with their son, Byron. His obituary describes him as the "second eldest son of Judge James Wolcott"
m. 11 FEB 1848 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio, Eliza Jane Border, b. 1825 ,, England, d. 1898 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
3 children.
(7) Robert Fulton Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 14 SEP 1824 Fort Wayne, Allen Co., Indiana, d. 1836 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesROBERT drowned in the Maumee River.

(7) Mary Ann Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 6 JUN 1827 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 30 APR 1891 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesMARY lived in her father's home after his death.
m. 1848 Fort Wayne, Allen Co., Indiana, Smith Gilbert, b. 29 OCT 1815 Newtown, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, d. 30 MAR 1879 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
3 children.
(7) Henry Clay Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 17 OCT 1830 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 7 APR 1882 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesHENRY had black hair and dark eyes, reflecting his mother's Indian bloodline. He was living at Wayne Co., Michigan, when he enlisted in Co. E, 16th Michigan Inf. Regt., serving for 2 years and fighting at the Battle of Manassas. He then returned to Ohio. In Jan. 1864, he enlisted in Co. E, 3rd Ohio Cav. Regt. Part of this service was a a Brigade teamster, delivering supplies. He was mustered out at Nashville on 14 Aug. 1865. His life after the war was said to have been " difficult". In 1880 he was single and living alone at Maumee, age 52, with no occupation.
m. Annie , b. 7 JUL 1846 , d. 16 JUN 1925 .
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Frederick Calhoun "Fred" Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 21 NOV 1834 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 24 JUL 1864 Atlanta, Fulton Co., Georgia.
NotesFREDERICK served in the 47th Ohio Inf. Regt., and was killed at the Battle of Atlanta. His name is also given as Frederick Allyn Wolcott.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) James Monroe "Tip" Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 3 DEC 1839 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 24 NOV 1917 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesJAMES served in the 130th Ohio Inf. Regt. in the Union Army during the Civil War. He was a dentist by profession, and served as Justice of the Peace. He filed a number of legal suits claiming property in the city of Fort Wayne based on old Indian treaties. In 1887 he was Waynesfield Township clerk and justice of the peace. He was appointed Mayor of Maumee in 1885, and elected to that office in 1887. He was also Secretary of the Maumee Board of Education in 1887. James was a Mason, a Democrat, and an Episcopalian. He spoke at the 1912 Wolcott Society reunion, and read an account of his family which was printed in the society's annual report..
m. Emma Randall, b. , d. .
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Emily B. Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. INFANT .
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.

(6) James Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 3 NOV 1789 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 5 JAN 1873 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesJAMES supervised the construction of a woolen mill on the Waterbury River for his father in 1813. In 1818 he moved to Delaware, Ohio, where he and Joseph S. Hughes constructed a woolen mill at Delaware, Ohio, which he managed fot two years. Here he joined the Episcopal church. He then moved to St. Louis, Missouri, where he married, and then settled at Fort Wayne, Indiana. He purchased 300 acres of land in Allen Co., Indiana in 1826 at Ft. Wayne. He and his wife and all their household goods were put in a boat and paddled down the Maumee River from Fort Wayne to Waynesfield, Ohio. In 1827 he purchased 300 acres of government land in Waynesfield Township for $1.25 an acre, and 377 acres in Lucas Co. He build a log house in what was then a wilderness and sold land to other settlers. In 1834-6 he built a two story frame house on the north bank of the river at Maumee in which he and his wife lived and died. He operated the Central House, Maumee's first "hotel" before establishing himself as a merchant. By 1837, his business, receiving and forwarding merchandise to Ft. Wayne and points west, was one of the largest in the area. He paid personal property taxes in Waynesfield Township in 1838. In 1838 he was elected to the first Maumee City Council, where he served as president. He also built wharves and shipyards along the river near his home. James commissioned construction of two steamboats, the "General Harrison", with a 150 ft. keel, launched in 1840, and the "James Wolcott". They operated between Maumee and Buffalo, New York, via Lake Erie. James was the first president of Maumee City Council in 1838. The following year he was elected Judge of the Lucas County Court of Common Pleas. In 1843 he was Mayor of Maumee. He was a founder of the Ohio Whig political party and a supporter of William Henry Harrison and Henry Clay. In 1860 he was at Maumee, with Fred K. and James Wolcott. James, William W., Eliza J., Zoe W., Byron, and James M. Wolcott were at Maumee in 1870. After his death, his home was occupied by his daughter Mary, and was willed to the Episcopal church about 1960. It is now a museum.
m. 21 NOV 1844 Caroline B. , b. 1815 ,, New Hampshire, d. .
Subtree size: 2 nodes.
1 child: Joseph Luke.
(7) Joseph Luke Wolcott7 (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1845 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesJOSEPH served as a musician in Co. B, 67th Ohio Inf. Regt., during the Civil War. In 1865 he was a lieutenant in the Loyal Legion of the United States. Joseph L. Wolcott of Toledo, Ohio, was an officer of the Paltrier Oil Company in 1897.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(6) Elizur "Eli" Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 JUL 1792 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. Enfield, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesELIZUR is said to have lived at Thompsonville. He was probably the Elizur Wolcott, age 50, born in Connecticut, who was living at a hotel in Enfield, Connecticut in 1850.

1850 Enfield, Harftford Co. CT: Elizur Wolcott 50y, b. CT, lodger at Harris family hotel.

1860 Eli Wolcott was a machinist living at Enfield, Connecticut, in 1860. Living with him was Sophia Moulton 57.
m. 1817 ,, Connecticut, Esther Lewis, b. , d. .

(6) Frederick Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 13 JAN 1795 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 24 JUL 1895 Stow, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesFREDERICK or another Frederick Woolcott owned 277 acres at Ashtabula, Ohio, in 1833, which he rented to Eli Sanford.
He was a farmer at Stow, Ohio, in 1850.
Frederick Wolcott M 52y

(7) Oliver Wolcott7 (Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. NOV 1825 ,, Ohio, d. 14 FEB 1826 Stow, Summit Co., Ohio.

(6) Frederick Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 13 JAN 1795 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 24 JUL 1895 Stow, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesFREDERICK or another Frederick Woolcott owned 277 acres at Ashtabula, Ohio, in 1833, which he rented to Eli Sanford.
He was a farmer at Stow, Ohio, in 1850.

Spouse NotesJOHN was a physician at Akron, Ohio, in 1880.
Subtree size: 1 node.

1 child.
(7) Frederick Wolcott7 (Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1834 Stow, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 23 MAY 1903 Cuyahoga Falls, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesFREDERICK was at Stow, Ohio, in 1870 with Catherine and Marchant Wolcott. He and his wife went from Ohio to Kansas by wagon train with a family named Hoit.. While crossing the Mississippi River they were attacked by Indians and several wagons were nearly lost. In Kansas home they built a sod house, enduring locusts, Indians, droughts and "The Great Prairie Fire". In 1880 Frederick was a farmer at Trego Co., Kansas. They later returned to Ohio.
m. 3 JAN 1866 Cuyahoga Falls, Summit Co., Ohio, Katherine Finley, b. South Bend, St. Joseph Co., Indiana, d. 5 NOV 1915 Troy, Bradford Co., Pennsylvania.
Spouse NotesKATHERINE wrote an accout of her move to Kansas in a covered wagon train which was published in Harpers Magazine. She andher father taught music at Trego Co., Kansas, in 1880. Katharyn was a niece of Martha Finley, author of the Elsie Dinsmore series of books.

m. 22 SEP 1868 Bryan, Williams Co., Ohio, Albert Elliot, b. 27 DEC 1839 , Coshocton Co., Ohio, d. 31 AUG 1913 Defiance, Defiance Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesALBERT enlisted in Co. G, 12th Ohio Cav. Regt. Nov. 1863 and was discharged as Sgt. Nov. 1854 He was a farmer at Richland, Ohio, in 1880, next to John B. Elliot, born 1838, and family, including brother Samuel born 1845 . Their father was born in Ireland, and their mother in Pennsylvania. In 1890 he was at Defiance Co., Ohio.

NotesCECELIA "was one of the early members when the local Ohio chapter was the only chapter in existance, about 1900, and the meetings were held in little Ohio towns such as Hudson and Silver Lake, Ohio." She lived at Hudson, Ohio.

0 children.
(7) Elizur Hitchcock7 (Eleanor Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 15 AUG 1832 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
NotesThe following sketch appears in History of Summit County, With an Outline Sketch of Ohio, edited by William Henry Perrin (Chicago: Baskin & Battey, 1881), p. 716:
"Dr. Elizur Hitchcock, physician, Akron; is a native of Summit County. He was born on his fathers farm in Tallmadge, Aug. 15, 1832, and is the fourth of seven children born to Lucius W. and Eleanor (Wolcott) Hitchcock. His parents were natives of Connecticut, his father coming on foot in 1822, to Tallmadge, where he bought a farm, married and raised his family. In 1873, he lost his wife, and left the farm, coming to Akron, where he now resides. Dr. Hitchcock remained at home until the spring of 1850, working on the farm and gaining such education as the schools of the neighborhood afforded. At 18, he entered the Western Reserve College at Hudson, where he studied two years, and then entered the Junior Class in Yale College, graduating there in 1854. During the next four years, he taught select schools in Tallmadge and Gustavus, dividing the time between them. In 1857, he began reading medicine with Dr. Dudley Allen, at Kinsman, Ohio, and in 1860, graduated at the Medical Department of the Western Reserve College, at Cleveland, having taken a course previously at Ann Arbor, Mich. He began his practice at Mecca, but in the following spring located at Orwell, where he remained two years. He then went into the army as Surgeon of the 7th O.V.I., and resigned after serving about sixth months. In the fall of 1863, he located in West Williamsfield, Ohio, where he remained until 1869, when he sold out his business and attended the Bellevue Hospital. In 1870, he came to Akron and has since practiced his profession here. He is a member and President of the Summit County Medical Society, and also a member of the Union Medical Association of Northeastern Ohio. On Nov. 24, 1861, he married Miss Hattie Reed, a native of Mecca, Trumbull Co., Ohio, by whom he had one child, Gertrude R. His wife died in May, 1864. In November, 1864, he married Miss Lucretia Kellogg, a native of West Andover, Ashtabula Co., Ohio, by whom he has two children -- Halbert K. and Lucius W."
m. 24 NOV 1861 Mecca, Trumbull Co., Ohio, Hattie Reed, b. Mecca, Trumbull Co., Ohio, d. 20 MAY 1864 West Williamsfield, Ashtabula Co., Ohio.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
1 child.
(7) Elizur Hitchcock7 (Eleanor Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 15 AUG 1832 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
NotesThe following sketch appears in History of Summit County, With an Outline Sketch of Ohio, edited by William Henry Perrin (Chicago: Baskin & Battey, 1881), p. 716:
"Dr. Elizur Hitchcock, physician, Akron; is a native of Summit County. He was born on his fathers farm in Tallmadge, Aug. 15, 1832, and is the fourth of seven children born to Lucius W. and Eleanor (Wolcott) Hitchcock. His parents were natives of Connecticut, his father coming on foot in 1822, to Tallmadge, where he bought a farm, married and raised his family. In 1873, he lost his wife, and left the farm, coming to Akron, where he now resides. Dr. Hitchcock remained at home until the spring of 1850, working on the farm and gaining such education as the schools of the neighborhood afforded. At 18, he entered the Western Reserve College at Hudson, where he studied two years, and then entered the Junior Class in Yale College, graduating there in 1854. During the next four years, he taught select schools in Tallmadge and Gustavus, dividing the time between them. In 1857, he began reading medicine with Dr. Dudley Allen, at Kinsman, Ohio, and in 1860, graduated at the Medical Department of the Western Reserve College, at Cleveland, having taken a course previously at Ann Arbor, Mich. He began his practice at Mecca, but in the following spring located at Orwell, where he remained two years. He then went into the army as Surgeon of the 7th O.V.I., and resigned after serving about sixth months. In the fall of 1863, he located in West Williamsfield, Ohio, where he remained until 1869, when he sold out his business and attended the Bellevue Hospital. In 1870, he came to Akron and has since practiced his profession here. He is a member and President of the Summit County Medical Society, and also a member of the Union Medical Association of Northeastern Ohio. On Nov. 24, 1861, he married Miss Hattie Reed, a native of Mecca, Trumbull Co., Ohio, by whom he had one child, Gertrude R. His wife died in May, 1864. In November, 1864, he married Miss Lucretia Kellogg, a native of West Andover, Ashtabula Co., Ohio, by whom he has two children -- Halbert K. and Lucius W."
m. 30 NOV 1864 Lucretia Kellogg, b. West Andover, Ashtabula Co., Ohio, d. .

2 children.
(6) George Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 26 JUL 1806 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 31 MAR 1857 Wolcottville, LaGrange Co., Indiana.
NotesGEORGE's father died when he was 15, leaving him in charge of the family farm at Tallmadge Ohio. In 1828, he went to Wadsworth, Ohio, where he purchased 100 acres of land at four dollars per acre, and began clearing it and building a log cabin. He bought half interest in a sawmill in 1832, and engaged in the manufacture of fanning mills. George moved to La Grange Co., Indiana, in 1837, and built a log cabin on the Elkhart River. He homesteaded 160 acres in LaGrange Co. jointly with Smith C. Sherman in 1838. Here he built a sawmill and gristmill, adding a store and a frame barn in 1839. The town was called Wolcott's Mills, but in 1848 the name was changed to Wolcottville, named after George. In 1845 he built a larger gristmill, bringing the machinery by wagon from Ann Arbor, Michigan, a distance of one hundred and sixty-five miles. In 1847 he built a larger store, putting into it a full stock of goods and conducting seven different branches of business; milling, sawing, coopering, blacksmithing, mercantile,and potash production. George also had a large farm. He requested the National Educational Society to send a teacher as governess for his family. The next year he built a school building that he named the Wolcottville Young Ladies Seminary. Later young men were admitted as well. Soon after this he built a boarding house with rooms for the students. The money used in these enterprises was from his own resources. The 1850 census has him as a miller at Johnson Township, LaGrange Co., Indiana, age 43, with Margaret 46, Abby A. 19, Esther R. 16, Elton 14, Marshall 12, and Amelia 8.
m. 6 AUG 1828 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Margaret Hine, b. 12 NOV 1803 North Milford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 2 FEB 1892 Wolcottville, LaGrange Co., Indiana.
Spouse NotesHine genealogy and history of the descendants of Thomas Hine of Milford, Conn., 1639, by Robert C. Hine (1899), p. 65-66
Subtree size: 9 nodes.
7 children: Anna Louisa "Ann", Abigail Amanda, Julia Almira, Esther Rowena, Elton Romeo, Marshall Franklin, Amelia.

NotesANNA was a member of the Wolcott Society 1914-15, residing at Kalamazoo Michigan.

(4) Josiah Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 6 FEB 1719 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 29 JUN 1802 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesJOSIAH served in Capt. E. Grant's Co. during King George's War. He apparently never married, although he is listed at East Windsor in 1790 with a household of 1 male over 16 and 2 females. He left an estate valued at 8,034L.

(4) Epaphras Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 8 FEB 1721 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 APR 1733 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(4) Erastus Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 21 SEP 1722 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 14 SEP 1793 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesERASTUS was a Representative to the General Assembly for South Windsor for many terms, and was Speaker of the Assembly. He was a Justice of the Peace, Judge of Probate, and Chief Judge of the County Court. Erastus was sent to Boston in 1775, to observe the British troops. He commanded a Regiment of Connecticut militia in 1776, which helped raise the siege of Boston. After the British left, he took his troops to New London where he supervised the erection of fortifications and garrisoned Fort Trumbull and Fort Griswold. In 1777 Erastus was in charge of the troops guarding the Hudson River. He led the 1st Connecticut Brigade in the expedition to Peekskill, New York, and then to Danbury, Connecticut. Erastus, leader of the agrarian faction in the state, was chosen a delegate to the Continental Congress, but did not accept. He was a member of the Court Martial selected by Washington for the trial of Major Andre. After the war, he was a Judge of the Connecticut Supreme Court. Yale College gave him an honorary degree. In 1790 he was at East Windsor with family consisting of 3 males over 16 and 1 female. Erastus' will, dated 14 Dec. 1792, left a silver tankard to his son, Erastus, 500L each to his daughters, Flavia and Jerusha, and the residue to be divided between his sons, Erastus, Arodi, and Albert. He was said to been of large frame, with light gray eyes and light hair, reserved in conversation, with a reputation for sagacity. He was affectionately known as "Old Long Head". Erastus and his wife, Jerusha, were 2nd cousins.
m. 10 FEB 1746 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Jerusha Wolcott, b. 18 JAN 1719 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 JUN 1789 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 117 nodes.
7 children: Erastus, Flavia, Erastus, Flavia, Jerusha, Arodi, Albert.
(5) Erastus Wolcott5 (Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 24 DEC 1747 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 AUG 1751 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(5) Flavia Wolcott5 (Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 27 MAY 1750 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 AUG 1751 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(5) Erastus Wolcott5 (Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 6 JUL 1752 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 JAN 1797 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesERASTUS was a Captain in the Connecticut Line, and commanded a regiment at Boston. He was taken prisoner by the British and suffered a long confinement. He lived in his father's house at Windsor, where he was a Justice of the Peace, a Representative to the General Assembly, and Judge of Probate. In 1790 he was at East Windsor with a family consisting of 1 male over 16, 2 males under 16, and 1 female. His estate was valued at $39,918. A land warrant was issued in 1799 to his wife, Chloe, guardian of his minor children, Erastus, Chloe, Edward, Julia, and Helen Wolcott, based on his military service. He was tall and thin, with light complexion, and light flaxen hair. Erastus and his wife were second cousins.
m. 27 DEC 1783 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Chloe Bissell, b. 30 AUG 1758 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 FEB 1802 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 17 nodes.
5 children: Erastus, Chloe, Edward, Juliana, Helen.
(6) Erastus Wolcott6 (Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 OCT 1784 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 27 FEB 1812 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.

(6) Chloe Wolcott6 (Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 19 APR 1786 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. Rochester, Monroe Co., New York.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(6) Edward Wolcott6 (Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 12 OCT 1788 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 9 NOV 1832 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesEDWARD was at Hartford Co., Connecticut, in 1810, as head of family consisting of 2 males age 16-25 (Erastus and Edward), 1 female 26-44, and 3 females age 16-25 (Chloe, Julianna, and Helen). He was captain of a company in Col. Shepard's Regt. in the War of 1812. His grave stone gives his rank as Captain.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(6) Juliana Wolcott6 (Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 APR 1791 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 30 NOV 1832 .
m. 13 MAY 1823 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Elihu Wolcott, b. 12 FEB 1784 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 DEC 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
Spouse NotesELIHU was a Representative to the Connecticut Legislature for East Windsor. He sold the family farm and moved to Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois in 1830. It was said that had a two room cabin, but that their furniture was shipped via New Orleans and did not arrive until the next spring. Elihu was a merchant and land owner. He purchased a large amount of land in 6 counties in Illinois between 1831 and 1849, including 952 acres at Orland Township, Cook Co., in 1835. In 1839 Elihu Woolcott of Morgan Co., Illinois, purchased 950acres of government land at Cook Co., Illinois, and 160 acres at Morgan Co., Illinois. He surveyed the route of the Sangamon and Morgan Railroad. Elihu was President of the Board of Trustees of the Jacksonville Female Academy in 1836. He ran as a candidate for Congress for the Liberty Party in 1846, against Abraham Lincoln and Cartwright. His estate was valued at $100,000. He won prizes at the 1853 Illinois State Fair for his cow and poultry. His son Elizur Wolcott was executor of his estate.
Subtree size: 4 nodes.
3 children: Helen Maria, Julia Ann, Ellen Louise "Ella".
(7) Helen Maria Wolcott7 (Juliana Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 JUN 1824 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 13 MAY 1831 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Julia Ann Wolcott7 (Juliana Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 20 JUN 1826 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 14 JUL 1910 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesJULIA was a student at the Jacksonville Female Academy, graduating in 1845.
m. 19 NOV 1846 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, William Chauncy Carter, b. 2 APR 1820 New Canaan, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, d. 9 DEC 1896 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
Spouse NotesWILLIAM came to Illinois in 1833. The family settled on a farm four miles south of Jacksonville in Morgan Co. He graduated from Illinois College in 1845 and taught school for a few years. He then purchased a farm next to his father's farm. His barn was a way station on the "Underground Railroad". In 1873 he moved into Jacksonbville, where he served eight years on the city council and Director of the school.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
9 children.
(7) Ellen Louise "Ella" Wolcott7 (Juliana Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 4 JUN 1828 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 15 APR 1912 Elmira, Chemung Co., New York.
NotesELLEN had a dermatalogical illness and spent much time undergoing various cures. After the death of her father she had financial problems. She worked for the Sanitary Comission as a nurse during the Civil War, where she was a correspondent of Dorthea Dix. After the war she was a librarian at Elmira, New York. In 1880 she was living alone at Elmira. Her letters and papers are in the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, at the University of Connecticut Library. Ellen L. Wolcott of Elmira, New York, is reported deceased in the 1912 Society report, and is described as "a loyal member of the society from its beginning."
m. McVaugh, b. , d. .

(6) Helen Wolcott6 (Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 MAR 1794 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 4 APR 1840 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York.
NotesHELEN attended Mrs. Royce's School for Girls at Hartford, as did her cousin, Ursula Wolcott.
m. 3 SEP 1822 , Ontario Co., New York, Horace Hooker, b. 5 JUL 1794 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 NOV 1865 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York.
Spouse NotesHORACE came to Carthage, New York, from Windsor, Connecticut, in 1821, and was engaged in comercial ventures. Carthage became part of Rochester.
Subtree size: 9 nodes.
8 children: Julia Wolcott, Henry Edward, Frances, James Wolcott, John Chaffee, Charles M., Thomas, Horace B..
(7) Julia Wolcott Hooker7 (Helen Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 11 APR 1823 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York, d. .
m. 12 JUL 1844 Josiah Wolcott Bissell, b. 3 MAY 1818 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York, d. .
Spouse NotesJOSIAH was engaged before the Civil War in banking, and in architectural and engineering work. During the war he was colonel of an engineer regiment attached to Gen. Pope's army, and superintended the construction of the canal that enabled the national gunboats to approach the confederate works on Island No. 10, in the Mississippi River.

NotesHENRY was a horiculturist at Rochester.

Spouse NotesSUSAN's biography was published in 1952 as "Susan Huntington Hooker, a Biography", by Kenneth Ward Hooker. Her letters and family papers are at the University of Rochester.

(5) Flavia Wolcott5 (Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 5 JAN 1754 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 MAY 1827 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 20 AUG 1783 ,, Connecticut, Roswell Grant, b. 9 MAR 1746 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 31 DEC 1834 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesROSWELL graduated from Yale in 1765. It is thought that he commanded the "Connecticut" in the naval engagement on Lake Champlain in 1776. He enlisted in the Continental service in 1778, and in the same year was appointed Captain. He served from July 1780 to December 1780 as commanding officer of the commissary of a Brigade of the Continental Army appointed by the Connecticut Legislature October 1780, for which he received a pension. After the war he served as paymaster and Judge Advocate. In 1794 he was appointed Lt. Col. of the 19th Connecticut Regiment. In 1812 he was the Captain of a company of volunteers.
Subtree size: 22 nodes.
8 children: Harry, Ebenezer, Henrietta, Ann, Roswell Henry, Sidney Algernon, Paschal Winthrop, Frederick William.

NotesFREDERICK took over his father's farm. He served as Corporal, Sgt., 2nd Lt., and Capt. of the 2nd Co., 1st Cav. Regt. He was appointed Major in the 1st Cav. Regt. in 1832.

(7) Elizabeth Lucy Grant7 (Frederick William Grant6, Flavia Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 29 AUG 1850 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 24 SEP 1851 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.

(5) Jerusha Wolcott5 (Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 29 NOV 1755 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 19 MAR 1844 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesJERUSHA was receiving a military pension in 1840, residing at East Windsor, Connecticut, with her daughter, Ursula Skinner.
m. 29 DEC 1774 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Samuel Wolcott, b. 4 APR 1751 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 JUN 1813 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesSAMUEL served in the Commissary of the 8th Connecticut Line during the Revolutionary War, and his wife, Jerusha, later received a military pension. He occupied a house in East Windsor, now South Windsor, where his children and grandchildren were born. This house stood on the home site of his grandfather, Henry Wolcott. Some of the materials used in the house are said to be from the original home. In 1790, his family at East Windsor consisted of 5 males over 16, 2 males under 16, and 6 women. Samuel was said to have been nearly six feet high, with robust frame, dark hair, and dark hazel eyes. His estate was valued at $30,669. His widow, Jerusha, age 81, applied for a military widow's pension in 1836 at Hartford, Connecticut.
Subtree size: 57 nodes.
8 children: Jerusha, Naomi, Samuel, Elihu, Sophia, Ursula, Elizabeth, Horace.

(7) Leverett Bissell7 (Jerusha Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. SEP 1807 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 21 SEP 1872 .

Subtree size: 1 node.

0 children.
(6) Naomi Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 10 OCT 1777 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 MAR 1831 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York.
m. 23 OCT 1804 , Ontario Co., New York, James Wadsworth, b. 20 APR 1768 Durham, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 7 JUN 1844 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York.
Spouse NotesJAMES was the a nephew of James Wadsworth, a Major General in the Continental Army. James graduated from Yale College in 1787. He briefly taught school at Montreal, Canada. He and his brother, William Wadsworth each obtained 2,000 acres of land in the Genesee Valley of New York. They moved there in 1790 and built a log cabin. By 1800 they owned 35,000 acres between them, most of which stayed in the family for many generations. James built a home for his new bride, Naomi, who he married in 1804. It was called "The Homestead". He was the chief founder of the town of Geneseo. He gave the proceeds from articles and lectures to establish the town's first library; advocated the idea of normal schools in 1811; accomplished the passage of a school library law in 1838, and established an institution for scientific lectures to which he gave an endowment fund of $10,000. He was the owner of vast tracts of land and in disposing of the same made the condition that 125 acres in every township be gratuitously set aside for a church, and an equal amount for a school. Over his life time, in contributed over $100,000 to education. He was a Brigadier General in the New York militia in the War of 1812.
Subtree size: 6 nodes.
5 children: Harriet, James Samson, William Wolcott, Cornelia, Elizabeth.
(7) Harriet Wadsworth7 (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 13 SEP 1805 , d. 1834 .
m. Martin Brimmer, b. , d. .
Spouse NotesMARTIN graduated from Harvard University in 1814. He was Mayor of Boston, Massachusetts.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
1 child.
(7) James Samson Wadsworth7 (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 30 OCT 1807 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 6 MAY 1864 Wilderness, Spotsylvania Co., Virginia.
NotesJAMES dropped out of Harvard, studied law with Daniel Webster, and was admitted to the bar in 1833. He married a "celebrated beauty" and took her to Europe for their honeymoon. Fascinated by the way the English gentry lived, he returned to Geneseo and built a palatial house called "Hartford House". He purchased 24,000 acres of government land in Ohio in 1836. He had a home in New York City, and maintained a racing stable and an impressive wine cellar. He entertained lavishly, his guests including many prominent government officials and European nobility. His house had nine servant rooms and other servants came in for the day. He divorced his first wife and remarried. In 1855, James took his family to France and England for two years. He was a leader in various agricultural movements, and was an unsuccessful candidate for Governor of New York. He was an outspoken opponent of slavery. James volunteered for the Union Army in 1861, and fought at the Battle of Bull Run and at Gettysburg. He was briefly Military Governor of Washington, D.C., and was nominated for Governor of New York in 1862. James commanded the Union troops at the Battle of The Wilderness in 1864, and died during the battle, reportedly after saying: "Steady boys. Come ahead. There isn't danger enough to harm a mouse." In 1868 he had an estate of 7,237 acres at Geneseo. The wil of James S. Wadsworth of Livingston, New York, dated 1856. recorded at Fulton Co., Ohio, states that he owned about 24,000 acres of land in Northwest Ohio, purchased fron the government in 1836. It mentions his children, Charles F. Wadsworth, Craig W. Wadsworth, James Wadsworth Jr., Cornelia, Nancy, and Elizabeth; nephew, Martin Brimmer; son-in-law, Montgomery Ritchie of Ritchey & Fitzhugh of New York City. His wife, Mary C. W. Wadsworth, is to have the home she was given in her fathers will dated 1837, and the home and library in New York City. He mentions various pieces of land formerly belonging to William A. Wadsworth, Livingston Wadsworth, and Herbert Wadsworth, infant children of William W. Wadsworth, and their mother, Emeline Wadsworth, and Charles James Murry, infant child of Elizabeth Wadsworth Murry.
m. 11 MAY 1834 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, Mary Craig Wharton, b. ABT 1811 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .

NotesWILLIAM remained a bachelor.

(7) Cornelia Wadsworth7 (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. ABT 1810 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .

(7) Elizabeth Wadsworth7 (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 26 JUL 1815 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 8 DEC 1851 Cairo,, Egypt.
NotesELIZABETH was considered beautiful and talented, and was courted by many men. She met her future husband when he visited America in 1834. Her father refused to consent to this marriage, but after his death she visited England and married Charles there in Westminster Abbey. She died following complications caused by the birth of her son.
m. 12 DEC 1850 London,, England, Charles Augustus Murray, b. 22 NOV 1806 ,, Scotland, d. 3 JUN 1895 .
Spouse NotesCHARLES was the second son of the Earl of Dunmore. He attended Eaton and graduated from Oxford. In 1834 he visited America, where he met his future wife. He was a member of the Queen's Household, and then was attached to the British Consulate at Naples. He was appointed British Consul-General to Cairo, and then to Berne. In 1854 he became the British Minister to Persia.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
1 child.
(6) Samuel Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 12 DEC 1781 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 17 FEB 1795 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(6) Elihu Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 12 FEB 1784 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 DEC 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesELIHU was a Representative to the Connecticut Legislature for East Windsor. He sold the family farm and moved to Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois in 1830. It was said that had a two room cabin, but that their furniture was shipped via New Orleans and did not arrive until the next spring. Elihu was a merchant and land owner. He purchased a large amount of land in 6 counties in Illinois between 1831 and 1849, including 952 acres at Orland Township, Cook Co., in 1835. In 1839 Elihu Woolcott of Morgan Co., Illinois, purchased 950acres of government land at Cook Co., Illinois, and 160 acres at Morgan Co., Illinois. He surveyed the route of the Sangamon and Morgan Railroad. Elihu was President of the Board of Trustees of the Jacksonville Female Academy in 1836. He ran as a candidate for Congress for the Liberty Party in 1846, against Abraham Lincoln and Cartwright. His estate was valued at $100,000. He won prizes at the 1853 Illinois State Fair for his cow and poultry. His son Elizur Wolcott was executor of his estate.
m. 27 NOV 1806 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Rachel McClure, b. 29 OCT 1783 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 APR 1822 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 10 nodes.
7 children: Elizabeth Ann, Elihu, Hannah McClure, Samuel, Arthur, Elizur, Frances Jane.
(7) Elizabeth Ann Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 26 DEC 1807 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
m. 28 NOV 1832 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, Carlton H. Perry, b. 1802 Arlington, Bennington Co., Vermont, d. Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
Spouse NotesCARLTON commanded a regiment during the Civil War. In 1880 he lived at Keokuk, Iowa, where he was described as a "capitalist".

(7) Elihu Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1808 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
