(7) Hannah McClure Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 JUN 1811 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 31 AUG 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
m. 28 NOV 1832 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, William Kirby, b. 2 JUL 1805 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 20 DEC 1851 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
Spouse NotesWILLIAM graduated from Yale in 1827. He went to Illinois as a member of the Yale band of missionarys. In 1846 the family moved to Jacksonville. He was Superintendant of Home Missions in Illinois. His wife, Hannah, and father-in-law, Elihu Wolcott were named guardian of his children, William, Frances, Catherine, Helen, and Bessie.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
7 children.
(7) Samuel Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 2 JUL 1813 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 24 FEB 1886 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
Notes SAMUEL graduated from Yale College in 1833 and gave the Commencement Oration. He graduated from the Andover Theological Seminary in 1837, and was ordained in 1839. In 1837 his name is at the head of a number of Andover students who issued an anti-slavery manifesto. Samuel was a missionary to Syria from 1840 to 1843. He is said to have been one of two Americans who were the first Westerners to climb to the Jewish stronghold at Masada in 1842. Returning to America he became pastor of the Longmeadow, Massachusetts, Congregational Church in 1843. Between 1843 and 1853 he was among the principal speakers at temperance conventions. He became minister at Belchertown, Massachusetts in 1849; The High Street Congregational Church at Providence, Rhode Island in 1853; The New England Congregational Church of Chicago, Illinois, in 1859; and finally at Plymouth Congregational Church, Cleveland, Ohio, in 1862. He was at Chicago, Illinois, in 1860, with Harriet A., Samuel A., Henry R., Edward O., Harriet A., William E., Catherine E., Ann L., and Caroline G. Wolcott. Samuel was given an honorary STD degree by Marietta College, in 1863. During the Civil War, he went South with the U.S. Christian Commission. He was at Cleveland, Ohio, in 1870, with Harriett, Kate, Annie, Clara, Herbert, and Lottie. Samuel resigned his church ministry in 1874 to become Secretary of the Ohio Home Missionary Society. He was a minister at Cleveland, Ohio, in 1880. In 1880 Samuel Wolcott was on a delinquent tax list for Jacksonville, Illinois. He was the author of numerous religious tracts and hymns, the best known being, "Christ for the World we Sing", published in the 1892 hymnal of the Protestant Episcopal Church and subsequently in hymnals of many other denominations. He was the author of the 1st Wolcott Genealogy "The Wolcott Memorial" published in 1881. He is described as being tall in stature, with abundant white hair and beard. His sons in Denver built a fine home at Longmeadow, Massachusetts, for his retirement.
m. 5 SEP 1839 Westminster, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, Catharine Elizabeth Wood, b. 17 DEC 1812 Westminster, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, d. 26 OCT 1841 Beirut,, Syria.
Spouse NotesThe Vital Records of Westminster, Massachusetts read "Wood, Catherine E. and Rev. Samuel Walcott of Jacksonville, Ill. [Int. Aug 17, 1839.]
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Samuel Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 2 JUL 1813 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 24 FEB 1886 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
Notes SAMUEL graduated from Yale College in 1833 and gave the Commencement Oration. He graduated from the Andover Theological Seminary in 1837, and was ordained in 1839. In 1837 his name is at the head of a number of Andover students who issued an anti-slavery manifesto. Samuel was a missionary to Syria from 1840 to 1843. He is said to have been one of two Americans who were the first Westerners to climb to the Jewish stronghold at Masada in 1842. Returning to America he became pastor of the Longmeadow, Massachusetts, Congregational Church in 1843. Between 1843 and 1853 he was among the principal speakers at temperance conventions. He became minister at Belchertown, Massachusetts in 1849; The High Street Congregational Church at Providence, Rhode Island in 1853; The New England Congregational Church of Chicago, Illinois, in 1859; and finally at Plymouth Congregational Church, Cleveland, Ohio, in 1862. He was at Chicago, Illinois, in 1860, with Harriet A., Samuel A., Henry R., Edward O., Harriet A., William E., Catherine E., Ann L., and Caroline G. Wolcott. Samuel was given an honorary STD degree by Marietta College, in 1863. During the Civil War, he went South with the U.S. Christian Commission. He was at Cleveland, Ohio, in 1870, with Harriett, Kate, Annie, Clara, Herbert, and Lottie. Samuel resigned his church ministry in 1874 to become Secretary of the Ohio Home Missionary Society. He was a minister at Cleveland, Ohio, in 1880. In 1880 Samuel Wolcott was on a delinquent tax list for Jacksonville, Illinois. He was the author of numerous religious tracts and hymns, the best known being, "Christ for the World we Sing", published in the 1892 hymnal of the Protestant Episcopal Church and subsequently in hymnals of many other denominations. He was the author of the 1st Wolcott Genealogy "The Wolcott Memorial" published in 1881. He is described as being tall in stature, with abundant white hair and beard. His sons in Denver built a fine home at Longmeadow, Massachusetts, for his retirement.
m. 1 NOV 1843 Millbury, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, Harriet Amanda Pope, b. 29 JUN 1821 Oxford, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, d. 5 FEB 1901 .

(7) Arthur Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 27 FEB 1815 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 28 NOV 1873 Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
NotesARTHUR was a merchant at Keokuk, Iowa, in 1850. He was at Keokuk in 1860 with Clara B. and Sarah M. Wolcott. His burial record says he was born 10 April 1815.
m. 12 JUL 1849 Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa, Sarah Ann Morrison, b. 10 DEC 1828 ,, Pennsylvania, d. 27 JAN 1851 .
Subtree size: 1 node.

(7) Arthur Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 27 FEB 1815 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 28 NOV 1873 Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
NotesARTHUR was a merchant at Keokuk, Iowa, in 1850. He was at Keokuk in 1860 with Clara B. and Sarah M. Wolcott. His burial record says he was born 10 April 1815.
m. 1854 Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa, Clara Belknap, b. ABT 1820 Newburgh, Orange Co., New York, d. 24 JAN 1906 Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
Spouse NotesCLARA came to Iowa from Ohio in the early 1850s, and was a long time member of the Presbyterian Church at Keokuk
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
3 children.
(7) Elizur Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 7 AUG 1817 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 10 MAR 1901 Berkeley, Alameda Co., California.
NotesELIZUR graduated from Yale in 1839, was a early member of the "Skull and Bones" Society. He was educated as a physician, but engaged in Railroading and milling. He was roadmaster for the Wabash Railroad, and was a member of the Jacksonville, Illinois, City Council and Board of Education. In 1860 Eleizer Wolcot was a "gentleman" at Jacksonville, Illinois, age 42, with Martha 35, Eddie 9, and Elihu 5 mo. In 1870, he and wife and daughters Edith and May were living at Jacksonville, where he is described as a retired miller. He planned and carried out a city system of water-works for Jacksonville, and planned the Diamond Grove Cemetery.
m. 15 JUL 1846 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, Martha Lyman Dwight, b. 25 APR 1824 ,, Massachusetts, d. 9 JAN 1900 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
Spouse NotesMARTHA's name is Marela D. Wolcott on her death record.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
4 children.
(7) Frances Jane Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 30 MAR 1819 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 11 OCT 1871 Hot Springs, Garland Co., Arkansas.
Notes"My Beloved Wife, Frances Wolcott Lewis, a native of East Windsor, Conn., died at Hot Springs, Ark., October 11th (1831?, 1871?)
m. 2 JUN 1849 Mobile, Mobile Co., Alabama, Barbour Lewis, b. ABT 1814 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, d. .
Spouse NotesBARBOUR served as a Major during the Civil War. He was a lawyer, a Member of Congress for Tennessee, and a Judge.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(6) Elihu Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 12 FEB 1784 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 DEC 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesELIHU was a Representative to the Connecticut Legislature for East Windsor. He sold the family farm and moved to Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois in 1830. It was said that had a two room cabin, but that their furniture was shipped via New Orleans and did not arrive until the next spring. Elihu was a merchant and land owner. He purchased a large amount of land in 6 counties in Illinois between 1831 and 1849, including 952 acres at Orland Township, Cook Co., in 1835. In 1839 Elihu Woolcott of Morgan Co., Illinois, purchased 950acres of government land at Cook Co., Illinois, and 160 acres at Morgan Co., Illinois. He surveyed the route of the Sangamon and Morgan Railroad. Elihu was President of the Board of Trustees of the Jacksonville Female Academy in 1836. He ran as a candidate for Congress for the Liberty Party in 1846, against Abraham Lincoln and Cartwright. His estate was valued at $100,000. He won prizes at the 1853 Illinois State Fair for his cow and poultry. His son Elizur Wolcott was executor of his estate.
m. 13 MAY 1823 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Juliana Wolcott, b. 9 APR 1791 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 30 NOV 1832 .
Subtree size: 4 nodes.
3 children: Helen Maria, Julia Ann, Ellen Louise "Ella".
(7) Helen Maria Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 JUN 1824 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 13 MAY 1831 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Julia Ann Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 20 JUN 1826 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 14 JUL 1910 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesJULIA was a student at the Jacksonville Female Academy, graduating in 1845.
m. 19 NOV 1846 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, William Chauncy Carter, b. 2 APR 1820 New Canaan, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, d. 9 DEC 1896 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
Spouse NotesWILLIAM came to Illinois in 1833. The family settled on a farm four miles south of Jacksonville in Morgan Co. He graduated from Illinois College in 1845 and taught school for a few years. He then purchased a farm next to his father's farm. His barn was a way station on the "Underground Railroad". In 1873 he moved into Jacksonbville, where he served eight years on the city council and Director of the school.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
9 children.
(7) Ellen Louise "Ella" Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 4 JUN 1828 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 15 APR 1912 Elmira, Chemung Co., New York.
NotesELLEN had a dermatalogical illness and spent much time undergoing various cures. After the death of her father she had financial problems. She worked for the Sanitary Comission as a nurse during the Civil War, where she was a correspondent of Dorthea Dix. After the war she was a librarian at Elmira, New York. In 1880 she was living alone at Elmira. Her letters and papers are in the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, at the University of Connecticut Library. Ellen L. Wolcott of Elmira, New York, is reported deceased in the 1912 Society report, and is described as "a loyal member of the society from its beginning."
m. McVaugh, b. , d. .
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
1 child.
(6) Elihu Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 12 FEB 1784 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 DEC 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesELIHU was a Representative to the Connecticut Legislature for East Windsor. He sold the family farm and moved to Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois in 1830. It was said that had a two room cabin, but that their furniture was shipped via New Orleans and did not arrive until the next spring. Elihu was a merchant and land owner. He purchased a large amount of land in 6 counties in Illinois between 1831 and 1849, including 952 acres at Orland Township, Cook Co., in 1835. In 1839 Elihu Woolcott of Morgan Co., Illinois, purchased 950acres of government land at Cook Co., Illinois, and 160 acres at Morgan Co., Illinois. He surveyed the route of the Sangamon and Morgan Railroad. Elihu was President of the Board of Trustees of the Jacksonville Female Academy in 1836. He ran as a candidate for Congress for the Liberty Party in 1846, against Abraham Lincoln and Cartwright. His estate was valued at $100,000. He won prizes at the 1853 Illinois State Fair for his cow and poultry. His son Elizur Wolcott was executor of his estate.
m. 17 SEP 1835 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Sarah Choate Crocker, b. 17 AUG 1797 , d. 4 AUG 1844 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
Subtree size: 4 nodes.
2 children: Sarah Elizabeth, Richmond,
(7) Sarah Elizabeth Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 12 MAY 1837 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 6 SEP 1838 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.

This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Richmond Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 10 JAN 1840 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 14 MAY 1908 Springfield, Sangamon Co., Illinois.
NotesRICHMOND gratuated from Illinois College in 1859. He was living at Morgan Co., Illinois, in 1860, with the Kirby family, and listed on the census as a physician. He enlisted as a Private in Co. B, 10th Illinois Infantry in 1861. In April 1861 he was a hospital steward at Jacksonville. He was later comissioned a Lieutenant, and then promoted to Captain. He was discharged in September, 1864. He was admitted to the bar in June 1865, and was a lawyer at Springfield, Illinois, where he was living with Jennie, Cordelia, and Lucy in 1880. He was one of the organizers and the first Secretary of the Illinois Sons of the American Revolution in 1889. Richmond wrote short stories, several of which were published in books and magazines in the 1860s. In 1870 Richmond Wolcott of Sagamon Co., Illinois, purchased 160 acres of government land at Otter Tail Co., Minnesota, and 12 acres at Grant Co., Minnesota.
m. 11 JUL 1865 , Sangamon Co., Illinois, Jane Van Vechten "Jennie" Satler, b. 17 OCT 1841 Waverly,, Illinois, d. 9 FEB 1920 St. Louis, St. Louis Co., Missouri.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
3 children.
(7) Richmond Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 10 JAN 1840 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 14 MAY 1908 Springfield, Sangamon Co., Illinois.
NotesRICHMOND gratuated from Illinois College in 1859. He was living at Morgan Co., Illinois, in 1860, with the Kirby family, and listed on the census as a physician. He enlisted as a Private in Co. B, 10th Illinois Infantry in 1861. In April 1861 he was a hospital steward at Jacksonville. He was later comissioned a Lieutenant, and then promoted to Captain. He was discharged in September, 1864. He was admitted to the bar in June 1865, and was a lawyer at Springfield, Illinois, where he was living with Jennie, Cordelia, and Lucy in 1880. He was one of the organizers and the first Secretary of the Illinois Sons of the American Revolution in 1889. Richmond wrote short stories, several of which were published in books and magazines in the 1860s. In 1870 Richmond Wolcott of Sagamon Co., Illinois, purchased 160 acres of government land at Otter Tail Co., Minnesota, and 12 acres at Grant Co., Minnesota.
m. Ida Anneliza , b. , d. 1 OCT 1861 .
Spouse NotesIDA's relationship to Richmond is unknown, but she is buried in the same cemetery with his daughter.

m. 19 OCT 1807 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Martin Ellsworth, b. 17 APR 1783 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 NOV 1857 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesMARTIN graduated from Yale College in 1801. He inherited his father's home and lands at Windsor.

NotesURSULA lived at East Windsor, Connecticut, in 1840.
m. 10 MAY 1815 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Newton Skinner, b. 10 OCT 1782 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 MAR 1825 New Britain, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesNEWTON graduated from Yale University in 1804. He was pastor of the New Britain Congregational Church. He lived at East Windsor, Connecticut, in 1840.

m. 6 OCT 1840 Aaron Russell Livermore, b. 6 OCT 1810 Mansfield, Tolland Co., Connecticut, d. East Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesAARON attended Amhurst College 1833-1836, and Lane Theological Seminary in 1837. He graduated from the East Windsor Hill Theological Seminary in 1839. He was a clergyman at East Haven, Connecticut, in 1880, age 70, with wife, Mary G. 62, and daughter, Mary C. 29

3 children.
(7) Samuel Wolcott Skinner7 (Ursula Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 19 JUN 1820 New Britain, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 AUG 1903 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesSAMUEL received a BA degree from Yale College in 1842 and a MA degree in 1846. He was liscenced as a medical doctor in 1846. He was Divison Surgeon with the 1st Connecticut Artillery at Arlington Virginia, from 1861 to 1865, during the Civil War. In 1866 he moved to Toledo, Ohio, where he had a medical practice. He served as the Toledo Health Officer and consulting surgeon for St. Vincent Hospital.
m. 16 SEP 1846 Dorianna Fuller, b. 18 OCT 1823 , d. 17 MAR 1919 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.

(6) Elizabeth Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 23 SEP 1791 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 FEB 1873 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 23 NOV 1820 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Erastus Ellsworth, b. 20 JAN 1790 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 30 APR 1879 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesERASTUS was a merchant and an elder in the Presbyterian Church in New York City. He purchased a home at East Windsor from his brother-in-law, Elihu Wolcott. He was a founder of the Theological Institute of Connecticut.
Subtree size: 6 nodes.
5 children: Erastus Wolcott, Elizabeth, , Mary Lyman, Josiah Leavitt.
(7) Erastus Wolcott Ellsworth7 (Elizabeth Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 27 NOV 1822 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 5 JAN 1902 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesERASTUS graduated from Amhurst College in 1844 and studied law but was never admitted to the bar. He was a poet and an inventor. In 1845 he obtained a patent for a drawing or copying instrument, and for a device for making a siphon discharge at its highest point. One of his poems, "What is the Use", was published in "An American Anthology", by Edmund Steadman. Erastus engraved some of the pictures that appeared in "The Wolcott Memorial".
Subtree size: 1 node.

m. 9 NOV 1848 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, William Wood, b. ABT 1823 Waterbury, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 9 AUG 1884 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesWILLIAM was a medical doctor. He was also an ornithologist, and the author of "The Birds of Connecticut".

(7) Josiah Leavitt Ellsworth7 (Elizabeth Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 25 MAY 1829 New York City, New York, d. 25 APR 1832 New York City, New York.

This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(6) Horace Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 25 MAR 1794 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1838 , Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesHORACE was Captain of a cavalry unit at South Windsor. He moved first to Michigan, where he was a petitioner at Monroe Co. in 1831 and 1834, and later to Illinois, where he died. Horace Wolcott of Hartford Co., Connecticut purchased 279 acres of government land at Lenawee Co., Michigan, in 1825, where he was a fur trader. Horace Wolcott of Monroe Co., Michigan, purchased 3 acres of land at Wayne Co., Michigan, in 1825. An additional patent for 80 acres of land in Lenawee Co., issued in 1825, was confirmed in 1931. His brother, Elihu, was administrator of his estate.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(5) Arodi Wolcott5 (Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 29 SEP 1760 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 18 MAY 1805 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. DEC 1789 , Hartford Co., Connecticut, Ruth Pitkin, b. 1764 East Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 AUG 1811 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.

(6) Almira Wolcott6 (Arodi Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 13 AUG 1793 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 FEB 1865 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALMIRA's grave stone says she died 27 Feb. 1865, age 71. She and her sister, Mary, raised Julia, daughter of Simon and Betsy Loomis of South Windsor. Julia married Zenas Rider of Springfield, Massachusetts.

m. Russell Cone, b. , d. .
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(5) Albert Wolcott5 (Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 19 DEC 1761 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesALBERT lived in the home built by his grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott, in 1704. He was at East Windsor, Connecticut in 1790, with a family of 1 male over 16, 1 male under 16, and 4 females. He was at Hartford Co. in 1810 with 1 male over 45 (Albert), 2 females 16-25 (Hannah & Cynthia), and 1 female 10-15 (Elizabeth). Following the death of his wife and only son, Albert and his four daughters, Cynthia, Hannah, Laura, and Elizabeth, moved to Cleveland, Ohio, in 1816. He brought with him the family Bible of his grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott, which was later deposited by his grandson, Stoughton Bliss, with the the Hartford, Connecticut, museum.
m. 26 APR 1786 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Hannah Loomis, b. 29 JUL 1765 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 11 JAN 1807 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 13 nodes.
6 children: Hannah, Albert, Cynthia, Laura, Laura, Elizabeth "Betsey".

m. Hannah Moore, b. ABT 1790 , d. ABT 1832 .

(6) Cynthia Wolcott6 (Albert Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 15 SEP 1789 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1848 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
m. 16 MAY 1813 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, William Bliss, b. 3 JAN 1790 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 8 SEP 1828 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesWILLIAM and his wife moved to Cleveland, Ohio, in 1815. He is considered the city's first silversmith. He also sold general goods and worked as a cabinet maker. He owned considerable property in Cleveland. They lived on Superior St., near West 3rd. Her father and sisters lived nearby. The Blisses were charter members of the Old Stone Church in Cleveland, Ohio. He died of malaria.
Subtree size: 7 nodes.
5 children: Albert Wolcott, Nancy Eliza, Louisa, Stoughton, William Samuel,

NotesLOUISA was born blind, and after her father's death was cared for by a cousin, Nancy Warner, Mrs. Proctor Pease, living in Michigan.

(7) Stoughton Bliss7 (Cynthia Wolcott6, Albert Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 18 FEB 1823 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesSTOUGHTON remained unmarried after the death of his wife. He lived at the Kennard House hotel at Cleveland. He is said to have strongly resembled Oliver Wolcott, signer of the Declaration of Independence.

(7) William Samuel Bliss7 (Cynthia Wolcott6, Albert Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 5 MAY 1827 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. 1881 Glenville, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesSAMUEL moved from Columbia, Tennessee, to Cleveland, Ohio, in 1872. In 1880 he was a newspaper publisher at Franklin, Indiana, but returned to Ohio where he died in 1881.

(4) Ursula Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 30 OCT 1724 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 5 APR 1788 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesURSULA was pictured in Ripley's "Believe It or Not" newspaper column because her father, brother, husband, son, and nephew were all Governors.
m. 10 NOV 1743 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Matthew Griswold, b. 25 MAR 1714 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 28 APR 1799 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesMATTHEW was a lawyer. He was a Representative to the General Assembly in 1759, and appointed Judge of the Superior Court in 1766. In 1769 he was elected Lieutenant Governor and Chief Justice of Connecticut. He served as Governor of Connecticut from 1784 until 1786, and was President of the state Convention for the adoption of the new Federal Constitution in 1788. He lived in the family home called Black Hall. Her eight daughter were sometimes known as "The Black Hall Boys".
Subtree size: 105 nodes.
8 children: Ursula, Hannah, Marian, John, Ursula, Matthew, Roger, Sally,
(5) Ursula Griswold5 (Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 18 NOV 1744 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 14 FEB 1745 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(5) Hannah Griswold5 (Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 17 APR 1746 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 15 DEC 1755 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(5) Marian Griswold5 (Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 17 APR 1750 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 17 JUN 1829 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
NotesMARIAN was considered a very beautiful, brilliant and outspoken woman. When Justin Ely, who became her 3rd husband, proposed marriage she replied, "Oh, I could not think of burying another husband." She died 12 years after him. Account books of the store and farm at Woodstock, Connecticut begun by her first husband were kept by Marion until 1811.
m. 28 SEP 1769 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, Charles Church Chandler, b. 11 JAN 1746 Woodstock, Windham Co., Connecticut, d. 9 AUG 1787 Woodstock, Windham Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesCHARLES graduated from Harvard College in 1763. He was a lawyer and member of the Committee of Correspondence and the Continental Congress. He had a store and farm at Woodstock, Massachusetts.

9 children: Dorothy Church, Samuel, Marion, Ursula, Charles, Hannah, Sally, Esther, Elizabeth.

(6) Elizabeth Griswold6 (John Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 15 OCT 1778 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 22 JUN 1857 .
m. 28 MAR 1802 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Jacob Baker Gurley, b. 2 AUG 1771 Mansfield, Tolland Co., Connecticut, d. 24 SEP 1856 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
Spouse Notes Jacob B. Gurley, Esq., pf New London, Conn., w'as born in the town of Mansfield, Tolland Co., Conn., Aug. 2, 1771 (house shows by photo.). He attended the common schools of the town, and graduated at Dartmouth College in 1793. He was principal or preceptor of the Union School at New London, studied law, and was admitted to the bar in 1797, and became one of the ablest lawyers in New London County. Mr. Gurley was one of the incorporators of the Savings Bank at New London, 1827. He was a public spirited man, and did much for the advancement of the town and city. Soon after the death of his father, he became the owner of the homestead, which he owned the remainder of his life, and rented it during these years to his son-in-law, Mr. An- son Turner. After the death of Mr. Gurley this farm came into the pos- session of his son-in-law, Mr. Charles A. Gurley, who kept it but a few years, and then sold it. This farm had been in the possession of the Gurleys for over a century, and is situated a little south of the old Gurley burying-ground. Charles Griswold Gurley, son of Jacob B. Gurley, Esq., graduated at Yale College, 1827, and died July 4, 1828.
Subtree size: 12 nodes.
11 children: Charles, Sarah, Mary Brainard, Charles, Elizabeth, Ursula Wolcott, Hannah Brigham, John Griswold, Ellen, Lydia Ann, Ann.

m. John Lyon Gardiner, b. 1770 , d. 1816 .
Spouse NotesJOHN was 7th lord of the manor of Gardiner's Island, the only entailed estate in America. His father died when he was 4 years old and his uncle, Abraham Gardiner was his guardian until he came of age in 1791.

(6) Ursula McCurdy6 (Ursula Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 20 AUG 1778 , d. ABT 1819 .
m. John Allen, b. 12 JUN 1763 , d. 31 JUL 1812 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesJohn studied law at the Litchfield Law School and was admitted to the bar in 1786. He was a member of the Connecticut House of Representatives 1793-6, and a Representative to Congress 1797-9, a member of the state Council and Supreme Court of Errors 1800-6, after which he practiced law at Litchfield. He was called "Long John Allen", and a poet.
Subtree size: 3 nodes.
1 children: John,
(7) John Allen7 (Ursula McCurdy6, Ursula Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1802 , d. 1887 Washington, District of Columbia.
NotesJOHN moved from Litchfield to study law at Cleveland, Ohio, under Judge Samuel Cowles, about 1825. He was admitted to the Cleveland bar, and was the last president of the village council. When Cleveland became a city he was mayor and postmaster, state Senator, Representative to Congress, banker, and railroad director.
m. Warren, Trumbull Co., Ohio, Anna Maria Perkins, b. , d. .
Spouse NotesANNA died three months after her marriage.

(5) Roger Griswold5 (Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 29 MAR 1762 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 25 OCT 1812 Norwich, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER graduated from Yale College in 1780 and was admitted to the bar in 1783. In 1794 he was elected to Congress to represent Lyme. He served there for ten years. His fight with Representative Matthew Lyon, which led to a physical fight on the floor of the House of Representatives, created quite a stir. He was offered the post of Secretary of War by John Adams, but declined. In 1807 he was appointed a Judge of the Superior Court, and in 1809 was chosen Lieutenant Governor. He was elected Governor of Connecticut in 1811.
m. 27 OCT 1788 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, Fanny Rogers, b. 23 MAR 1767 Norwich, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 27 DEC 1863 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 45 nodes.

NotesROBERT was a ship Captain.

(7) Louise Augusta Griswold7 (Robert Harper Griswold6, Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 8 OCT 1841 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 12 APR 1896 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesLOUISE was the organist for the First Congregational Church at Old Lyme for 40 years.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Helen Adele "Adele" Griswold7 (Robert Harper Griswold6, Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 29 MAR 1844 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 27 FEB 1913 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesHELEN and her sister, Florence, lived in the family home after their mother's death, taking in borders and selling plants and vegetables from their garden to make ends meet. In 1899 the artist, Henry Ward Ranger, came to board with them, and he encouraged other artists to stay there and to form an artist's colony at Old Lyme. Shortly after the colony was formed, Adele got tuberculosis and went to live in a sanitarium at Hartford, after which Florence ran the boarding house.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Robert Harper Griswold7 (Robert Harper Griswold6, Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 1847 , d. 21 SEP 1864 .
NotesROBERT died of dyptheheria at age 16.

(7) Florence Griswold7 (Robert Harper Griswold6, Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 25 DEC 1850 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 6 DEC 1937 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesFLORENCE ran the family home as a boarding house for artists and an art gallery after her sister moved to a sanitarium. In 1921 the Lyme Art Association opened a gallery next to her home on land she gave them for this purpose. She was considered a patron of the American Impressionist movement. She became the first manager of the gallery, receiving a percentage of the sales. In 1936 a conservator was appointed for her and her property sold, but she retained life tenancy. The home is now th "Florence Griswold Museum.

This is the final generation of the tree.

(4) Oliver Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 20 NOV 1726 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 DEC 1797 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesOLIVER WOLCOTT, born 20 Nov. 1726 Windsor, Connecticut; died 1 Dec. 1797 Litchfield, Connecticut, buried East Cemetery, Litchfield. Oliver graduated first in his class from Yale in 1747. In the same year he was commissioned a Captain by Gov. Clinton of New York and raised a company of men which he lead in defense of the northern frontiers against the French and the Indians. After the peace of Aix-la-Chapelle his unit was disbanded and he returned to Connecticut and studied medicine under his brother, Alexander. Oliver moved from Goshen, Connecticut, to Litchfield about 1750. In that year his father was elected Governor of Connecticut. From 1751 to 1771 he was Sheriff of Litchfield County. In 1753 he built a large house at Litchfield, on land given him by his father. This home is the oldest house at Litchfield, and was lately occupied by his descendant, Mrs. Alice Wolcott Sherman. Washington and Lafayette visited the home, and Washington stayed here on his visit to Litchfield in 1780. He married Laura Collins 21 January 1755, by whom he had five children, one dying in infancy. One son, Oliver Wolcott. Jr., was a Governor of Connecticut. Oliver was elected a Representative to the Connecticut General Assembly in 1764 and served until 1770. He was an Assistant to the Governor from 1771 to 1786. He was also a Judge of Probate from 1772 to 1795, and chief Judge of the Court of Common Pleas from 1774 to 1786. He rose through the ranks of the Connecticut militia, from Captain to Major-General. In 1775, he was appointed one of the Commissioners of Indian Affairs, charged with inducing the Indians to remain neutral during the struggle with Great Britain. He was appointed as a representative of Connecticut to the Continental Congress in 1776, taking his seat there in January, 1776. Becoming ill in June, during the discussion of the Declaration of Independence, he returned to Connecticut. He led fourteen units of the Connecticut militia to the defense of New York. On 9 July, 1776, a group of patriots tore down the lead statue of George III on Bowling Green in New York City. Oliver had it taken by cart to his home at Litchfield. His family and neighbors melted the lead in the Wolcott's apple orchard, molding 42,000 bullets for Washington's army. He returned to Philadelphia where he signed his name to the Declaration of Independence on 4 September 1776. Oliver spent the summer of 1777 recruiting troops from Connecticut, and with the rank of Major General, he commanded the Connecticut militia at the Battle of Saratoga, where British General Burgoyne was defeated. He rejoined the Continental Congress at York, Pennsylvania, and went with it when it moved to Baltimore in the winter of 1777-8. He signed the Articles of Confederation as representative for Connecticut on 15 Nov, 1777. In 1779 he commanded a division of militia defending the Connecticut coast. In 1780, he was one of the three commissioners appointed to arrange for supplies for the French troops at Newport, Rhode Island. He served with the militia until 1780, and, except for 1799, he represented Connecticut in the Continental Congress until 1784. In 1784 and 1785 he was one of the Commissioners for Indian Affairs charged with establishing terms of peace with the Iroquois. He helped negotiate the "Purchase of 1784", which legally cleared all Indians from the land northwest of the Allegheny River. Oliver, and his sons, Oliver and Frederick, were given land grants at Elmore, New Hampshire, for his service in the wars. He was also given land near Wolcott, New Hampshire, named for him because of his support for making New Hampshire a state. He was a member of the Susquehanna Company, a group of Connecticut investors who sold land in the Wyoming Valley to settlers. This land was claimed by both Connecticut and Pennsylvania. At a meeting of the Susquehanna Company in 1785, he is said to have presented a draft of a constitution for a new state in that area, to be called "Westmoreland". He was involved in negotiations for resolving the "Wyoming Controversy". The resuts of this negotiation was that the Wyoming Valley belonged to Pennsylvania. He was also involved in negotiating a land dispute between Vermont and New York. Oliver was a slave owner. In 1786 he freed a slave named Caesar, giving him the surname, Jamus. In 1790, his family at Litchfield consisted of 3 males over 16, 1 female, and 6 slaves. From 1786 to 1796 Oliver was Lieutenant Governor of Connecticut. He was an ardent Federalist. He was granted an honorary LLD degree by Yale University. In 1796 he was a Presidential Elector and voted for John Adams. Upon the death of Governor Huntington, he became Governor of Connecticut, holding office until he died the following year. The town of Farmingbury, Connecticut, changed it's name to Wolcott when Oliver cast the tie-breaking vote in 1796, to allow it to seperate from the town of Waterbury, of which it had been a part. Oliver was described as tall, erect, and dignified, with a dark complexion. Two portraits of him, painted by Ralph Earle, have survived. One was presented to the State Senate of Connecticut by his grandson, Dr. John Stoughton Wolcott. It is now in the Connecticut State Library. The other is owned by the Connecticut Historical Society. Oliver's letters and papers are deposited with the Connecticut Historical Society. His statue was one of those placed on the Connecticut State House, added in 1916 by a vote of various Connecticut patriotic societies.
m. 21 JAN 1755 Laura Collins, b. 1 JAN 1732 Guilford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 19 APR 1794 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesLAURA's portrait, painted by Ralph Earl, is in the Virginia Art Museum in Richmond, Virginia.
Subtree size: 84 nodes.
5 children: Oliver, Oliver, Laura, Mariann, Frederick,
(5) Oliver Wolcott5 (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 31 AUG 1757 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 13 SEP 1757 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
Subtree size: 1 node.
0 children.
(5) Oliver Wolcott5 (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 11 JAN 1760 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 1 JUN 1833 New York City, New York.
NotesOLIVER attended Nathaniel Beckwith's grammar school, and in 1773 enrolled at Yale College. He served with the Litchfield militia in 1777 when they fought to keep the British from capturing the colonist's supplies at Danbury. He graduated from Yale in 1778, at the age of 18, and served as an military aide to his father in 1779. He studied law at Litchfield, and was admitted to the bar in 1781. He was a member of the Susquehanna Land Company in 1786. Oliver began practicing law in Hartford, and became a clerk in the state Treasury office, and was a member of the pay-table committee from 1782 to 1788, Connecticut State Comptroller of Public Accounts 1788-9, Auditor 1789-91, Comptroller of the U.S. Treasury 1791-5, and U.S. Secretary of the Treasury 1795-1800, succeeding Alexander Hamilton in the Cabinets of Presidents Washington and Adams. He resigned due to slander from his Republican opponents, being accused of starting a fire in the Treasury office to conceal peculations. Oliver was appointed by President Adams as a Judge of the Circuit Court in 1801, and served until 1802. He then established a mercantile business in New York City, where he was President of the Merchants' Bank of the City of New York from 1803 to 1804. He was living in Ward 2, New York City, in 1810, with a family of 1 male born before 1765 (Oliver), 1 male born 1765-85 (servant ?), 2 males born 1800-10 (Oliver, John), 2 females born 1775-85 (servants ?), and 2 females born 1785-95 (Laura, Elizabeth). These may have included his Negro servants, Julia b. 1780, Peggy Zillah born 1786, Chloe born 1788, and Chloe born 1791. He was one of the founders, and President of the Bank of North America from 1812 to 1814. Oliver and his brother, Frederick, established a large woolen mill on the Naugatuck River in Torrington Township in 1813, and the village of Orleans there was changed to Wolcottville in their honor. This became the city of Torrington in 1881. In 1815 Oliver was an unsuccessful candidate for Governor of Connecticut on the Democratic ticket. He was elected Governor of Connecticut in 1817, and was President of the Connecticut Constitutional Convention in 1818. He served as Governor until 1827. He was an ardent Federalist, an intimated friend and advisor of Washington, Adams and Hamilton, and for some time was the last surviving member of Washington's Cabinet. Oliver was associated with Julius Demming and Benjamin Tallmadge in the Litchfield China Trading Company. One of their ships, "The Trident", sailed between America and China for 14 years. Oliver was Grand Master of the Masonic Lodge of Connecticut from 1818 to 1820. He was awarded honorary LLD degrees from Yale, Princeton, and Brown Universities. Oliver purchased a large home at Litchfield near his father's house where his brother, Frederick, lived. He planted 13 sycamore trees along South St. at Litchfield, commemorating the 13 colonies. All but one of these were killed by disease, so Oliver and his brother planted elm trees to replace them. After retiring from public service, Oliver lived with his son, John, in New York City. His will left "to my beloved and only surviving son, Doctor John Stoughton Wolcott, who resides with me and is the protector of my declining years," all his books and papers and household effects and his home and property at Litchfield; $100 to his son-in-law William Gracie; and the remainder to be divided between his children, John and Laura. He requested that John provide for the support and education of his grandson, Oliver WolcottIV. In 1844 his sole surviving heirs were Mrs. Laura Gibbs of New York City, and a grandson, Oliver Wolcott of Litchfield, Connecticut.

"28 Jan. 1796, Philadelphia: letter from Wm. V. Murray to George McHenry on his nomination as Secretary of War: ... as to the Salary, it will maintain you in that easy style of elegant but quiet accomodation which I think you love at all events it does Wolcott & Pickering. The first lives in Fourth South, at the corner of Spruce, in a
neat house of two rooms, one small, on a floor and must I think live within his means. He is a very worthy man & quite equal to his duty; his wife one of the mildest & most amiable women in town an excellent manager, kind but economical.

Oliver's portrait was presented to the Connecticut State Senate by his son, Dr. John Stoughton Wolcott. A facimile of it was put on the 2 cent Revenue Stamp in 1945. His letters and papers were deposited with the Conneticut Historical Society.

A painting of Oliver dated 1806 said to have been painted in 1806 for the Hon. Josiah Quincy and bequeathed by him to Oliver Wolcott Gibbs (1822-1908); or alternatively, it was given by the subject to his daughter, Mrs. George Gibbs III (Laura Wolcott), who gave it to her son, Oliver Wolcott Gibbs. Oliver Wolcott Gibbs' niece, Laura Henriette d'Oremieulx, later Mrs. J. West Roosevelt, New York, great-granddaughter of the subject; her gift in 1933 to her son, Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt, New York (died July 15, 1953); owned by 1966, Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt, Jr., Birmingham, Alabama (on permanent loan to Birmingham Museum of Art, Birmingham, in 1997, still owned by O.W. Roosevelt, Jr.. A copy of this portrait is owned by George Gibbs, New York. See also the copy by G.L. Nelson owned by New-York Historical Society, New York. This copy by Nelson is owned by First National City Bank of New York (Citibank). A copy is at the United States Treasury Department.
m. 1 JUN 1785 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Elizabeth Stoughton, b. 27 OCT 1767 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 SEP 1805 New York City, New York.

(6) Laura Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 10 APR 1794 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 10 DEC 1870 New York City, New York.
NotesLAURA was strong and fortright, according to her grandson. She was an ardent abolitionist, and helped hide runaway slaves in New York City. Later in life she became an amateur artist.
m. 27 DEC 1810 New York City, New York, George Gibbs, b. 7 JAN 1776 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island, d. 6 AUG 1833 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
Spouse NotesGEORGE was a gentleman farmer on Long Island. He had a large house called "Sunswick", near Astoria, New York, overlooking the East River. He was an amateur scientist and mineralologist. The mineral, Gibbsite, was named for him. He was named vice-president of the New York Lyceum of Natural History in 1822. His huge collection of rocks and minerals, formed by the purchase of European collections and his own purchases, was the largest in the United States. The collection was purchased by Yale University in 1825. His large collection of books, purchased when he was in Europe, is now in the Yale University library. The Smithsonian Institution's Museum of American History has a five piece silver tea set with the Gibbs coat-of-arms, showing three battle-axes, made by Chaudron of Philadelphia, probably before 1819. This was owned by George and Laura, and may have been a wedding present. His father-in-law, Oliver Wolcott, lived with him at the time of Oliver's death.
Subtree size: 8 nodes.
7 children: George, Mary, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza", Oliver Wolcott "Wolcott", Alfred, Laura Wolcott, Francis Sarason.
(7) George Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 17 JUL 1815 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 19 APR 1873 New Haven, Oswego Co., New York.
NotesGEORGE attended the Round Hill School of Northampton, and graduated from Harvard College in 1838. In his early 20s he travelled extensively in Europe, making scetches of towns in Germany and Switzerland. This sketch book was in the possession of his descendant, Robert Nowell Williams Jr.. He was a lawyer, antiquarian, and Librarian of the New York Historical Society. In 1846 he published "Memoirs of the Administration of Washington and John Adams, Edited from the Papers of Oliver Wolcott, Secretary of the Treasury". George marched overland from St. Louis to Oregon in 1854. He was appointed Collector of the Port of Astoria, Oregon, in 1854, and served on the Boundary Commission. He was appointed to the boundary survey team in 1857. In 1860 he returned East and was employed by the Smithsonian Institution editing documents about Indian culture. He was the author of several works on Indian languages published by the Smithsonian. He moved to New Haven, Connecticut in 1871. He gave the chest owned by Henry Wolcott, the immigrant, to the Connecticut Historical Society. He married his first cousin.
m. 11 APR 1871 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island, Mary Kane Gibbs, b. 19 JAN 1827 , d. 18 DEC 1876 .

(7) Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 8 JUL 1819 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 25 AUG 1906 Stockbridge, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
m. 2 APR 1844 New York City, New York, Lucius Tuckerman, b. 19 MAR 1818 Chelsea, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 10 JUN 1890 Stockbridge, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesLUCIUS was a merchant in New York City, living at Manhattan in 1880. In 1879 he built a six story apartment house on Washington Square exclusively for bachelors, which became the home of notable artists such as Winslow Homer, Albert Ryder, Rockwell Kent, Edward Hopper, etc. He was an early benefactor of the Metropolitam Museum of Art and on the Social Register.
Subtree size: 1 node.

9 children.
(7) Oliver Wolcott "Wolcott" Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 21 FEB 1822 New York City, New York, d. 9 DEC 1908 .
NotesOLIVER dropped his first name at an early age, and called himself "Wolcott Gibbs". He entered Columbia College in 1837 and graduated in 1841. He then attended the College of Physicians and Surgeons there, qualifying as a medical doctor in 1845. He studied chemistry at the University of Berlin in the laboratories of Rose and Rammelsberg, and subsequently spent five months with Liebig in Giessen, returning to America in 1848. In that year he became professor of Chemistry at the Free Academy, which later became the University of the City of New York. In 1863 he became Rumsford Professor of Science at Harvard University which he held until his retirement in 1887. During the Civil War he was a member of the Executive Committee of the Sanitary Comission. In 1873 he was granted a LLD degree, and was appointed comissioner to the Vienna Exhibition. he was an honorary member of the German Chemical Society and the London Chemical Society, and one of the original members of the National Academy of Scienc. He is credited for introducing research into university requirements. In organic and analytical chemistry he discovered many new substances and developed new methods. His study of complex ammonia bases, double compounds, acids of metal, and metals of the platinum group, contributed markedly to the science of chemistry.
m. 1853 Josephine Mauran, b. , d. 16 FEB 1887 .
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Alfred Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 22 APR 1823 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 26 DEC 1868 Fort Leavenworth, Leavenworth Co., Kansas.
NotesALFRED graduated from the West Point Military Academy in 1846, and served in the Mexican War. As a Captain in the Civil War, he was taken prisoner by the Confederates and exchanged 27 August 1862. He was commissioned Colonel of the 130th New York Regiment of Volunteers on 6 September 1862. He reorganized his regiment as the 1st New York Dragoons in August 1863. He was appointed Brigadier General 19 Oct. 1864, and commanded a Brigade under Gen. Sheridan until 1865. He was present at the surrender of Gen. Lee. He mustered out of the army as a Major General 1 February 1866. He was then made a Major in the 7th U.S. Cavalry on 28 July 1866, serving under Gen. George Custer.
m. 27 DEC 1856 Richmond, Henrico Co., Virginia, Peggy Forshee Blair, b. JAN 1825 Richmond, Henrico Co., Virginia, d. 25 JUL 1908 .

m. 1853 Theophile Marie Oremieulx, b. 11 MAY 1815 ,, France, d. 3 JUL 1881 .
Spouse NotesTHEOPHILE came to America to fight in the Revolutionary War. He was an officer in the American Army, and an Assistant Professor at West Point Military Academy.

(7) Francis Sarason Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 24 JUN 1831 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 27 DEC 1882 New York City, New York.
NotesFRANCIS spent two years in Shanghai, China, as a resident agent for "Wolcott, Bates & Co.", a trading company. He returned to America and was in the grain exporting business in New York City. His firm failed when an English firm, which held the shipments on consignment, failed.
m. 6 JUN 1860 Eliza Gay Hosmer, b. 27 OCT 1836 New York City, New York, d. 24 NOV 1883 .
Spouse NotesEliza was frequently ill and spent time in California for her health . The children received some of their early education in Santa Barbara.

(6) Oliver Stoughton Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 18 JAN 1800 ,, New York, d. 23 MAY 1832 New York City, New York.
NotesOLIVER attended the U. S. Military Academy at West Point, and then was attached as Midshipman to the "Chesapeake". After he left the Navy he settled in Litchfield, Connecticut, and then moved to New Jersey. Later, his father lived with him in New York City. An 1833 court case, DuBois v. Hepburn, says that Oliver S. Wolcott, lessee of the plaintiff of land in Lycoming County, was born in Connecticut, but was domiciled in the state of Pennsylvania on 25 Sept. 1830. A painting of him by an unknown artist is in the Frederick Co., Maryland Historical Society.
m. 9 NOV 1820 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, Jane Lowe Conard, b. 17 SEP 1803 , d. 1845 .
Spouse NotesJANE's portrait is in the Frederick Co. Historical Society, Frederick, Maryland.

NotesOLIVER received his MD at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York City. He lived in Argentina and died unmarried.

(6) John Stoughton Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 4 DEC 1802 New York City, New York, d. 22 NOV 1843 New York City, New York.
NotesJohn S. Wolcott of CT was admitted to West Point 1 Sept. 1818, age 15 yrs 8 mo.

John practiced medicine at Litchfield, and later in New York City, where his father lived with him. Paintings of his father and grandfather Wolcott were presented by him to the Connecticut Senate in 1834. In 1925, miniature portraits of him and of his father, and a Latin text book inscribed with his name were presented to Peter Clark Wolcott for the Wolcott Society by Mrs. Olive K. Walden. Her aunt had been engaged to John.

April 8, 1844, Alexandria Gazette (Virginia): DIED: In Litchfield, Conn. Dr. JOHN STOUGHTON WALCOTT. His death was occasioned by the effects of arsenic and morphine, applied to the cavities of two hollow teeth, for the purpose of destroying the sensitiveness of their nerves.

(5) Mariann Wolcott5 (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 16 FEB 1765 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 12 MAR 1805 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesMariann's portrait, painted by Ralph Earl, is in the Litchfield, Connecticut, Museum.
m. 13 OCT 1789 ,, Connecticut, Chauncey Goodrich, b. 20 OCT 1759 Durham Township, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 18 AUG 1815 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesCHAUNCEY graduated from Yale in 1759, and then studied law with Charles Chauncey. He moved to Hartford to practice law in 1781. In 1793 and 1794 he represented New Haven in the State Legislature. In 1794, he was elected to the U.S. Congress where he served until 1801. In 1802 he was chosen a member of the Council, the upper branch of the state legislature, where he served until he became a U.S. Senator in 1807. In 1813 he was elected Lt. Governor of the State of Connecticut, and Mayor of Hartford.

(5) Frederick Wolcott5 (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 2 NOV 1767 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 28 MAY 1837 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesFREDERICK graduated from Yale College in 1786, delivering the the salutatorian oration in Latin. He was Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas in 1793, and clerk of the Superior Court at Litchfield in 1798. In 1796 he was appointed Judge of Probate. He inherited his parents home on South Street at Litchfield in 1797. His black servant, Hebe Williams died at Litchfield in 1803. Frederick was elected as Representative to the Connecticut General Assembly in 1808, and in 1810 was elected to the State Senate, an office that he held until 1823. He was a partner with his brother, Oliver, in the development of the woolen mills at a place that became known as Wolcottville. He and his brother imported cattle from England and sheep from Spain, and worked to improve American breeds of cattle and sheep. During the Revolutionary War he provided public service in Connecticut. He and his wife sold 200 acres of land at Norwalk, Ohio in 1822, part of the estate of her first husband, Amos Cook.
m. 12 OCT 1800 Norwich, New London Co., Connecticut, Elizabeth "Betsey" Huntington, b. 8 NOV 1774 Norwich, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 2 APR 1812 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.

6 children: Mariann Goodrich, Hannah Huntington, Joshua Huntington, Elizabeth Huntington, Frederick Henry "Fred", Laura Maria.
(6) Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 9 AUG 1801 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 26 APR 1864 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
m. 22 MAY 1827 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, Asa Whitehead, b. 26 MAY 1795 Livingston, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 2 JUN 1860 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
Spouse NotesASA was a leading Newark lawyer. He was a Delegate to Whig National Convention from New Jersey in 1839, and member, Committee on Permanent Organization; member of New Jersey state senate from Essex County, 1849-51. He raised and educated his nephew, John Whitehead, who became president of the New Jersey SAR and vice-president of the national SAR.

NotesFREDERICK was a railroad clerk at Newark, New Jersey, in 1880, with Ada, Huntington, Aaron P., and Normee (?) Whitehead.

(6) Joshua Huntington Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 29 AUG 1804 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 6 JAN 1891 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesJOSHUA was a merchant. He entered the textile comission house, A. and A. Lawrence in Boston as an apprentice, and became a partner at age 26. When Abbott Lawrence was appointed Minister to England in 1849, Henry took over as managing partner of the firm. In 1857 J. Huntington Wolcott was a commercial merchant at 82 Milk St., Boston, residing at 48 Boylston, Boston. He was at Milton, Massachusetts, in 1860, with wife, Harriet, and son, Roger Wolcott, and a commercial merchant with A. A. Lawrence & Co. in Boston. He was Senior Partner when the firm dissolved in 1865. He was prominent in the development of New England manufacturing as president and director of many companies. He was involved in many charitable enterprises, and was state treasurer of the Sanitary Commission during the Civil War. He was a member of the Society of the Cincinnati, of which his grandfather was an original member. He was engaged to Elizabeth Flint of Nashville, Tennessee, but the engagement was broken. A marble bust of him is in the Newark Museum, and his papers are at the Massachusetts Historical Society.
m. 12 NOV 1844 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Cornelia Frothingham, b. 11 DEC 1824 Cambridge, Middlesex Co., Massachusetts, d. 1 JUN 1850 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
Subtree size: 3 nodes.
2 children: Huntington Frothingham, Roger.
(7) Huntington Frothingham Wolcott7 (Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 4 FEB 1846 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 10 JUN 1865 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesHUNTINGTON was comissioned 23 Oct. 1864 as a 2nd Lt. in I Co., 2nd Regiment, Massachusetts Cavalry, during the Civil War. He served as an aide to his relative, Gen. Alfred Gibbs. At the end of the war, he participated in a Grand Review at Washington D. C., and two days later took ill with "camp fever". He returned to his father's home, where he died a week later from typhoid.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(7) Roger Wolcott7 (Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 13 JUL 1847 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 DEC 1900 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesROGER graduated from Harvard in 1870 and delivered the Class Oration. He received his LL.B. from Harvard Law School in 1874, and was a lawyer at Boston. He was a Member of the Boston Common City Council, 1877-79; the House of Representatives, 1882-84; Lieutenant-Governor of Massachusetts, 1892-95; became Governor upon the death of Governor Greenhalge in 1896 and was elected Governor, 1897-1898. He was the first President of the Republican Club of Massachusetts in 1891, a member of the Massachusetts Historical Society, Society of the Cincinnati and Loyal Legion and Society of Colonial Wars. He was overseer of Harvard University, 1885-1895, and Director and Trustee in many business and charitable organizations. In 1891 he established funds at Harvard in memory of Hunting Frothington Wolcott to benefit the Peabody Museum, and in memory of Joshua Huntington Wolcott to benefit the Harvard Library. A large bronze statue of him by Daniel Chester French graces the main lobby of the Massachusetts State House in Boston.

1910 Milton MA:
Edith P Wolcott F 57y
William P Wolcott M 30y
Cornelia F Wolcott F 25y
Oliver Wolcott M 19y
Dehlia A Ryan F 27y
Margaret M Queeney F 64y
Margaret M Walsh F 28y
Catharine Kenney F 27y
Ellen Carbac F 43y
John G Madden M 36y
William Brennan M 19y
Robert Crellin M 23y

Find A Grave memorial No. 10634892.
m. 2 SEP 1874 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Edith Prescott, b. 20 APR 1853 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 15 JUN 1934 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesEdith's great-great grandfather, Col. William Prescott, was Commander of American troops at the Battle of Bunker Hill. In 1899, she presented the Bunker Hill Monument to the town of Pepperell, placed on the Pepperell Common. Find A Grave memorial No. 45433906.
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
6 children.
(6) Joshua Huntington Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 29 AUG 1804 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 6 JAN 1891 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesJOSHUA was a merchant. He entered the textile comission house, A. and A. Lawrence in Boston as an apprentice, and became a partner at age 26. When Abbott Lawrence was appointed Minister to England in 1849, Henry took over as managing partner of the firm. In 1857 J. Huntington Wolcott was a commercial merchant at 82 Milk St., Boston, residing at 48 Boylston, Boston. He was at Milton, Massachusetts, in 1860, with wife, Harriet, and son, Roger Wolcott, and a commercial merchant with A. A. Lawrence & Co. in Boston. He was Senior Partner when the firm dissolved in 1865. He was prominent in the development of New England manufacturing as president and director of many companies. He was involved in many charitable enterprises, and was state treasurer of the Sanitary Commission during the Civil War. He was a member of the Society of the Cincinnati, of which his grandfather was an original member. He was engaged to Elizabeth Flint of Nashville, Tennessee, but the engagement was broken. A marble bust of him is in the Newark Museum, and his papers are at the Massachusetts Historical Society.
m. 12 NOV 1851 Harriet "Hattie" Frothingham, b. 1810 Cambridge, Middlesex Co., Massachusetts, d. .

(6) Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 6 MAR 1806 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 15 OCT 1875 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
m. 22 MAY 1827 Pompton Plains, Morris Co., New Jersey, John Peter Jackson, b. 8 JUN 1805 Acquackanonk,, New Jersey, d. 10 DEC 1861 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
Spouse NotesJOHN graduated from Princeton College in 1823. He was a lawyer, member of the New Jersey General Assembly 1831, Speaker of the House, Clerk of Essex Co. in 1839, Secretary of the New Jersey Railroad Company 1832, Director 1836-1861, Vice President and General Manager 1849.

(7) Frederick Wolcott Jackson7 (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 24 AUG 1833 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 14 JUN 1904 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
NotesFREDERICK studied at the Sheffield Scientific School at Yale University, graduating in 1852. He joined Norwood & Co. in New York City, and in 1855 went to work for New Jersey Railroad. He became General Superintendant of the United New Jersey Railroads, Pennsylvania Co..
m. 12 OCT 1859 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, Nannie Jane Nye, b. 5 AUG 1835 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 10 MAR 1905 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.

(7) Joseph Cooke Jackson7 (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 5 AUG 1835 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 22 MAY 1913 New York City, New York.
NotesJOSEPH graduated from Yale College in 1857. He received a LLB degree from Harvard University in 1860 and was admitted to practice law in New York City in 1860. He was commissioned Lt. Col. of the 6th New Jersey Volunteers in December 1862 for his gallant action at Fredericksburg, Virginia, December 11-15, 1862. He was brevetted Brigadier General, March 13, 1865. He was appointed U.S. Assistant District Attorney for the Southern District of New York by President Grant in 1870. After the war he was an attorney in New York City. He visited Tolland, Somerset, in 1903 and 1907, and joined the Wolcott Society in 1913 residing at New York City. In 1912 he privately published a 93 page book, "European and American Family of Wolcott". Some things said in that book were erronius.
m. 12 OCT 1864 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Katharine Perkins Day, b. 24 FEB 1837 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 NOV 1914 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.

(7) John Peter Jackson7 (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 6 FEB 1837 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 17 DEC 1880 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
NotesJOHN graduated from Princeton College in 1856 and received a LLB degree from Harvard in 1858. He was an attorney at Newark, New Jersey. He was a member of the Newark City Council 1866-70, and was Speaker of the New Jersey Legislature 1862-63.

(7) Huntington Wolcott Jackson7 (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 21 JAN 1841 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 3 JAN 1901 ,, Illinois.
NotesHUNTINGTON entered the College of New Jersey in 1859, but left at the end of his junior year to join the army. In 1863 he was brevetted Lt. Colonel. He was badly wounded at Kenesaw Mountain. He graduated from Harvard Law school in 1865, and was admitted to the Bar in 1868. He practiced law in Newark and Chicago, and in 1888 he was president of the Chicago Bar Assn. He apparently never married. A bronze tablet to his memory was placed in the Marshall Field store in Chicago.

(7) Schuyler Brinckerhoff Jackson7 (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 16 JUN 1849 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 28 JUL 1915 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
NotesSCHUYLER graduated from Yale College in 1871, and from Columbia Law School in 1873. In 1879 he was an alderman at Newark 1879-80 and a member of the New Jersey legislature 1878-79. He became Speaker of the General Assembly of New Jersey in 1879. He was a member of the Wolcott Society 1914-15, residing at Newark, New Jersey.
m. 27 FEB 1889 Angela Forbes, b. , d. .
Subtree size: 1 node.
This is the final generation of the tree.
0 children.
(6) Frederick Henry "Fred" Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 19 AUG 1808 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 13 APR 1883 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
NotesFREDERICK was a merchant in New York City. In 1860 he was living at Newtown, Queens, with Sarah E., Elizabeth H., Alice, Frederick, and Gardner H. He was much interested in family history, and hired H. G. Somerby to research the Wolcott family in England. It was largely through his interest and using his papers that Samuel Wolcott compiled the "Wolcott Memorial", the first published genealogy of the family. The book was privately distributed in 1886. Frederick owned the Oliver Wolcott house at Litchfield.
m. 12 JUN 1838 ,, New York, Abby Woolsey Howland, b. 11 NOV 1817 New York City, New York, d. 14 JUN 1852 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
Spouse NotesABBY was a descendant of John Howland who came to America on the Mayflower.

Spouse NotesStephen was a merchant in New York City. He and his wife lived with her father in 1880.

NotesALICE never married. She owned and lived in the Oliver Wolcott house at Litchfield. In 1922 she sold it to her niece, Alice Sherman.

(6) Laura Maria Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 14 AUG 1811 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 7 FEB 1892 .
NotesLAURA went to live with her maternal grandparents at Norwich, Connecticut, shortly after her father remarried. She lived with them for nine years. In 1825 she was sent to Sarah Pierce's school for girls at Litchfield. In 1880, Laura was at Newburgh, New York, with daughters, Laura M., Frances W., Mary W., and Cornelia W. Wolcott
m. 11 MAR 1831 Newburgh, Orange Co., New York, Robert Gosman Rankin, b. 29 JUN 1806 New York City, New York, d. 6 MAR 1875 Newburgh, Orange Co., New York.
Spouse NotesROBERT was raised by a friend of his father who resided at Ulster, New York. He graduated from Yale College in 1826, worked in a law office in New York City for one year, and then attended the Tapping Reeve Law School at Litchfield, Connecticut. He became a lawyer in 1829, marrying 2 years later Laura Wolcott who he met while studying law at Litchfield. He worked for various railroads and manufacturers. Robert was an Elder of the Presbyterian Church, and was elected a Regent of The University of the State of New York in 1846. In 1852 he moved to Astoria, Long Island, where he was a consulting engineer. He became president of the Mexican Mail Company in 1853, and later managed a coal mining company. He moved to Newburgh, New York, in 1863 because of poor health.
Subtree size: 13 nodes.
12 children: Frederick Wolcott, Huntington Wolcott, Ann, Henry, Robert Gosman, Laura Maria, Charles Chauncey Wolcott, Katherine Almedea, Frances Wolcott, Francis Huntington, Mary Wolcott, Cornelia W. "Nellie".

NotesFREDERICK graduated from Williams College in 1849.

(7) Francis Huntington Rankin7 (Laura Maria Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 25 SEP 1845 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York, d. 9 NOV 1896 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island.
NotesFRANCIS graduated from the Medical Department of New York University in 1869. He studied in Vienna for a year, and then went to Berlin where he was given an appointment as Acting Assistant Surgeon in the Prussian Army, and then Acting Surgeon. On returning to America he was given the steel medal of thanks from the Prussinan government. He began practice in New York City in 1871. In 1876 he moved to Newport and joined practice with Dr. Austin Sands who died the following year. He was a founder and President of the Newport Medical Society, and attending physician at the Newport Hospital. He was a frequent contributor to medical journals.
m. 11 NOV 1879 Grace Voorhis, b. , d. .

(5) Frederick Wolcott5 (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 2 NOV 1767 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 28 MAY 1837 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesFREDERICK graduated from Yale College in 1786, delivering the the salutatorian oration in Latin. He was Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas in 1793, and clerk of the Superior Court at Litchfield in 1798. In 1796 he was appointed Judge of Probate. He inherited his parents home on South Street at Litchfield in 1797. His black servant, Hebe Williams died at Litchfield in 1803. Frederick was elected as Representative to the Connecticut General Assembly in 1808, and in 1810 was elected to the State Senate, an office that he held until 1823. He was a partner with his brother, Oliver, in the development of the woolen mills at a place that became known as Wolcottville. He and his brother imported cattle from England and sheep from Spain, and worked to improve American breeds of cattle and sheep. During the Revolutionary War he provided public service in Connecticut. He and his wife sold 200 acres of land at Norwalk, Ohio in 1822, part of the estate of her first husband, Amos Cook.
m. 21 JUN 1815 Danbury, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, Sarah Worthington "Sally" Goodrich, b. 7 AUG 1785 Berlin, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 14 SEP 1842 .
Spouse NotesSARAH was heir of her husband, Amos Cooke, to 100 acres of land near Norwalk, Huron Co., Ohio, which she and her husband, Frederick Wolcott, sold to Harvey Webb in 1822.
Subtree size: 15 nodes.
4 children: Charles Moseley, Chauncey Goodrich, Henry Griswold, Mary Frances.
(6) Charles Moseley Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 20 NOV 1816 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 20 NOV 1889 New York City, New York.
NotesCHARLES was a merchant. His home on the eastern bank of the Hudson River, near Fishkill Landing, was called "Roseneath". He was at Fishkill in 1860, with wife, Catherine, and children, Henry, Catherine, and Ann. In 1863 he made a gift of 6 acres of land to St. Anna's Episcopal Church at Fishkill. C. M. Wolcott was at Fishkill in 1870, when the census says he was born in Massachusetts. With him was his wife, Catherine, and his three children. In 1880, he was a retired merchant, living at Matteawan, Dutchess Co., New York.
m. 1 NOV 1843 Roxbury, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Mary Elizabeth Goodrich, b. 26 OCT 1818 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 13 NOV 1845 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.

1 child: Frederick.

(6) Charles Moseley Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 20 NOV 1816 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 20 NOV 1889 New York City, New York.
NotesCHARLES was a merchant. His home on the eastern bank of the Hudson River, near Fishkill Landing, was called "Roseneath". He was at Fishkill in 1860, with wife, Catherine, and children, Henry, Catherine, and Ann. In 1863 he made a gift of 6 acres of land to St. Anna's Episcopal Church at Fishkill. C. M. Wolcott was at Fishkill in 1870, when the census says he was born in Massachusetts. With him was his wife, Catherine, and his three children. In 1880, he was a retired merchant, living at Matteawan, Dutchess Co., New York.
m. 26 NOV 1849 New York City, New York, Catharine Almandia Rankin, b. 6 JAN 1817 New York City, New York, d. 24 JUN 1889 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York.
Spouse NotesCATHERINE was New York State Regent for the D.A.R..
Subtree size: 4 nodes.
3 children: Henry Goodrich, Katharine Rankin, Annette Rankin.
(7) Henry Goodrich Wolcott7 (Charles Moseley Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 16 JUL 1853 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York, d. 2 APR 1906 Genoa,, Italy.
NotesHENRY graduated from Yale with a Ph.B. in 1873, and from Columbia College, LLB, in 1877. In 1892 he was a lawyer at Fishkill with Julia L., Oliver, Charles W., Elizabeth, and Katherine Wolcott. He was a member of the New York Bar, a lawyer, U.S. Commissioner, and Lt. Col. in the 21st Regiment, New York Guards. He resided at Roseneath, Fishkill-on-the-Hudson, but practiced law at Matteawan, a neighboring village.
m. 22 MAY 1879 New York City, New York, Julia Sterling Hutchins, b. 17 JUL 1855 New York City, New York, d. 15 FEB 1930 Red Bank, Monmouth Co., New Jersey.
Spouse NotesJULIA bought a large home on the Shrewsbury River at Red Bank in 1928. She was DAR member #10156.

This is the final generation of the tree.
6 children.
(7) Katharine Rankin Wolcott7 (Charles Moseley Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 29 APR 1855 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York, d. 2 NOV 1941 Beacon, Dutchess Co., New York.
NotesKATHERINE was President of the National Society of Colonial Dames, and Regent of the Daughters of the American Revolution. She was a member of the Wolcott Society in 1914, co-vice president for New York, and a member of the Historical Committee.
m. 8 APR 1896 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York, Samuel Verplanck, b. 20 JUL 1840 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York, d. 15 DEC 1911 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York.
Spouse NotesSAMUEL Verplanck of Matteawan was one of the wealthiest men in Dutchess County, and probably its wealthiest land owners. He and his wife and Mrs, Rankin of Newburg were shot while out driving near Newburg 12 Aug. 1901. It was found to be an accident by someone squirrel hunting.

(7) Annette Rankin Wolcott7 (Charles Moseley Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1) b. 29 JUN 1857 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York, d. .
Subtree size: 1 node.
